PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 500 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace located in Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only Church built in Lithuania after World War II;
(2) This Church was closed by the Soviet authorities on 15 August, 1960 and confiscated in 1961 under the direct order of Mr Khrushchev.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs to raise with its counterpart in the USSR the great concern of many Australians that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the religious worshippers of Klaipeda in Lithuania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MCLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 52 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry Mr Nixon M.P:

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and that at 1 October 1981 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25 per cent and that at the 1 October 1981 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

(3) Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 36 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 25 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commmonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principal that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailments of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 12 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 11 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Federal Government funding to the performing arts through the Australia Council has declined since 1974 by 39 per cent in real money terms.
2. Unless this funding is substantially increased in forthcoming federal budgets, many companies will be forced to cease operations and the performing arts will eventually wither and die.
3. A healthy and variegated performing arts scene is vital to any country that claims to be civilised.
4. The people of Queensland, particularly, value the performing arts and believe that without them, their lives would be significantly impoverished.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will substantially increase funding to the performing arts and will not allow the decline to continue at the alarming rate that has characterised the past seven years from 0 .12 per cent of total government outlays in 1974-75 to 0.07 per cent in 1981-82. And that the present single line appropriations are rescinded and the distribution of federal arts funding is left in the hands of the Australia Council.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed hydro-electric developments in South-West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support, or, if necessary, to initiate a Federal Inquiry into South-West Tasmania.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to
(1) reject any moves towards divorce by post;
(2) restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage;
(3) protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will;
(4) ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage;
(5) encourage counselling towards reconciliation;
(6) restore objective tests of irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
We pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Parliament condemns the scandalous announcement of the Minister for Housing and Construction that the Government will spend $300,000 in a propaganda campaign to publicise the Government's new housing policy, a campaign whose only beneficiaries could be the Victorian Liberal Party at next week's State election , and calls on the Government to immediately abandon this reprehensible waste of taxpayers funds in line with its own now discredited rhetoric, and to immediately redirect these funds from propping up the Victorian Liberal Party to supporting people in genuine need, by such measures as increasing the miserly $ 500,000 allocated for 1981-82 to emergency relief agencies in the face of a demonstrated annual need for over $12m to be spent in that area, or by providing the $40,000 required from the Commonwealth for the youth accommodation services pilot scheme for Latrobe Valley young people to the end of the current financial year, or by increasing spending on that Latrobe Valley project into next year, or by raising the permissible income for unemployment benefits from the current ridiculously low level of $3 per week for under 18 year olds.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator McLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate-
1. Condemns the extravagant claims made by the South Australian Liberal Premier , Mr Tonkin, and his Deputy, Mr Goldsworthy, about the proposed Roxby Downs uranium mine; and
2. Notes with concern that these false claims have been fully exposed in the Roxby Downs Indenture Bill which has now been referred to a South Australian Parliamentary Select Committee:

(a) Mr Tonkin's claim of 6 February 1979 that at a conservative estimate the Roxby Downs project would create 20,000 jobs has now been exposed as incorrect with only 2,000 to 3,000 jobs being mentioned in the Indenture Bill.

(b) His statement of 11 June 1980 that a township the size of Mt Isa with a present population of 26,000 people would be created when in actual fact the Indenture Bill provides for a town with a population of only 9,000 people.

(c) His statement in December 1981 that the State would receive $100m per annum in royalties has now proved to be without credibility in view of the Indenture Bill revealing that the amount is likely to be around $20m to $30m at best.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. By some strange coincidence it has a familiarity with the notice of motion given by my colleague, Senator Robert Ray. I refer the Minister to the Government's decision to spend $300,000-$100,000 in Victoria-on an advertising campaign designed to explain the new housing policy and also to rescue the Liberal Government before the State election on 3 April. Has not the Prime Minister continually complained in recent speeches about the lack of understanding of the Government's policies in the electorate? Is the Minister aware that the task force on departmental information released earlier this year -a Fraser Government task force-reported that a significant number of people were being disadvantaged because they did not know about Government welfare programs? Is it a fact that the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty found that in 1973 some 17,000 households were entitled to some kind of pension or benefit but were not receiving one, largely through ignorance? Did the task force of the Fraser Government advert to this fact? Will the Minister see that at least part, if not all, of the $100,000 allocated for the Victorian advertising campaign is directed at people who are living in poverty and are not being told by the Government that they are entitled to benefits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government's housing policy aims to provide about $400m worth of extra credit through lending agencies and thus provide many thousands of people with homes. It also aims to provide tax rebates and a new home savings grants system. I would have thought that everybody would have agreed that in order to help these people the specific nature of these programs should be brought to their attention regardless of whether an election is to be held in a particular State. For example, I notice that no one is suggesting that we should not advertise in Tasmania. However, the question relates to the dimension and principle of this matter. In the 1975-76 expenditure of the then Whitlam Government an amount of--

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The noise, for those who may not understand, is because the Australian Labor Party does not want it to be understood that when it projected a particular program it spent six to 10 times more on it. I repeat that in 1975 dollars the Labor Party spent $854,644 on projecting its Medibank program, compared--
—It pre-paid the States what was due in the next financial year after that shonky accountant had rigged the figures.

—If the Labor Party's only answer is to attempt to shout people down the people outside in the community will understand that that is a substitution for reasoned argument. I was asked whether it was a good or bad thing to spend $300,000 on advertising a housing policy, the knowledge of which would enable thousands of decent Australians in all States to get a house. The answer to that question is yes. It is a good thing. The dimensions of the advertising pale into insignificance compared with the programs of advertising used to launch Labor Party programs in the past, not to mention the millions of dollars that the Wran Government spends year by year on its public relations campaigns to the detriment of the people of New South Wales.

—I ask a supplementary question arising from the Minister's answer. Firstly, in view of his concern that the policy should be explained to the Australian people why is one third of the total sum being spent in the State of Victoria? Secondly, why has the Government not acted on its task force recommendations in relation to explaining Government policies? Thirdly, will the Minister table the costs of Government advertising of the five new health schemes that the Fraser Government has introduced since it came to office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr McVeigh, make a statement this morning to the media giving the reason that some 35 per cent of the expenditure was in Victoria. From my recollection he indicated that the television spot rates were higher in that State. I will seek information on that. I have no doubt in the world that we are observing the recommendations of the task force. I repeat the very simple fact that this is a particularly good housing policy. It will help tens of thousands of people. I cannot believe that the Australian Labor Party would want to deny people the right to know about it. I will direct the final question about costs to the Minister responsible and ask him to give it study.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC AND CULTURAL ORGANISATION CONVENTIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the written request dated 30 December 1981 to the Minister and the Prime Minister by the Australian Advisory Council on Bibliographical Services urging the Government to ratify the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention concerning the International Exchange of Publications of 1958 and its Convention concerning the Exchange of Official Publications and Government Documents between States of 1958. Is the Minister aware that the two conventions which were adopted at the General Conference of UNESCO at its tenth session in 1958 and which came into force in 1961 are considered essential to developments in the exchange of publications for the free exchange of ideas and knowledge among peoples of the world? Is it the intention of the Australian Government to ratify these conventions? If so, when will the Government take action to ratify the two conventions as testimony to its belief in the benefits that accrue to all people through the exchange of ideas and its desire to collaborate with other signatories, especially those in the Third World, that might benefit from ideas, knowledge of Australia's operations, and data in statistical and textual form.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware of some of the important matters raised by Senator Missen but at this stage I am not able to give him information on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I recently made some inquiries with regard to some of these matters but I have not yet received from the Minister for Foreign Affairs an up to date statement of the position. I will see whether I can obtain that as soon as possible and advise Senator Missen.

—Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate seen the comment by Mr Harry Martin, the Director of Community Aid Abroad, that the Government's promise to increase aid to the Third World by $100m is a sham? Did the Government promise the extra $100m in last year's Budget? Have the decisions of the razor gang left the Australian Development Assistance Bureau too short staffed to devise and implement new aid programs? How does the Minister reconcile this situation with the Prime Minister's posturing as a champion of the needs of the Third World at last year's Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —How one can find vice within virtue is only for members of the Australian Labor Party to describe. The recent Budget allocated $100m more for aid abroad, and that has been recognised throughout the world as a very significant gesture towards the developing countries, the so-called Third World. I have no reason to believe that there is an impediment in the general development of the program at all. I thought that the increase in the Budget would have had the full support of the Labor Party. Now, like all Jeremiahs, its members are knocking these things. I will look at Mr Martin's statement and ask the Minister concerned whether he desires to comment on it. If so, I will bring the answer to the attention of the Senate.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise whether the Federal Government has given consideration to the concept that the Commonwealth contribution to local government should become a percentage of total taxation receipts, rather than a percentage of personal income tax so that the real value of the contribution to local government is maintained? Does the Minister not agree that this would be a worthwhile means of ensuring that more realistic and adequate funds are returned to local government for much needed projects and works?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question was raised last year, I think, when the Commonwealth Government was reviewing the States' personal income tax sharing arrangements that had been instituted in 1976. It was decided then that the local government tax sharing arrangements should continue to be based on net personal income tax collections. The value of the Commonwealth's tax sharing grants to local government increased by 60 per cent in real terms based on net personal income tax between the 1976 year and the 1981-82 year. As I understand it, some local government associations are of the view that it is in local government's best interests for personal income tax to continue as the base for tax sharing assistance rather than total taxation.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose views could differ as to whether local government would have an advantage using total taxes as against personal income tax after looking at figures for one year or another. As I said, the arrangements were reviewed in 1981 and it was decided to continue them. With the growth we have seen, I think many local governments consider the arrangements satisfactory. I know of no prospect of changing them in the near future but of course that, in common with many other matters, will always be subject to study and decision at the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I appreciate that part of my question might infringe on questions of policy, which I understand the Minister cannot answer, but in regard to that part of the question which relies on fact I would ask him to draw on his resources not only as a Minister but also as a distinguished physician. Is it true that the Australian Medical Association--
—Ha, ha!

—If Senator Grimes is exercising any professional jealousy I will call him, too, a distinguished medical practitioner. Is it true that the Australian Medical Association is not recognised as a rampant socialist body? Is it equally true that it recently made a submission to the Industries Assistance Commission estimating that the social and health costs of smoking in Australia ranged between $650m and $950m every year? Is it further true that the AMA in its submission alleged that the Government provides the Australian tobacco industry with subsidies and assistance of the order of $26m every year? In other words, is it true that the Government or the taxpayer is subsidising an industry to the extent of $26m a year which is costing the taxpayer up to $950m a year? Would the Minister care to have a stab at justifying the logic behind that decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp is quite correct when he says that--
—That you are a distinguished physician.

—I pick up the interjection from Senator Grimes and ask that it be recorded in Hansard. After all, I was at one stage-briefly-Senator Grimes' s teacher in medicine. It is true, as Senator Chipp says, that the AMA is not known to be a rampant socialist body. It is also true that the Australian Medical Association, as part, I think, of an emerging policy of responsible social intervention, made a submission recently which was reported in the newspapers. It had to do with the costs of smoking and the extent of subsidy of the tobacco industry. Any policy matters concerning that subsidy are obviously matters for the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I acknowledge some of the points made by Senator Chipp. He talked about the cost of smoking being estimated at between $650m and $950m a year. Firstly, the costs are enormous. Secondly, it is very hard to identify them with precision. The honourable senator will acknowledge that the figures given are very broad. The subsidy to the industry is quite considerable but I ask the Senate to note that the Government, in responding to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, made two points: The Government is committed as a matter of policy to diminishing the extent of smoking in Australia and it accepts the enormous health costs associated with cigarette smoking generally. I think those two acknowledgments by the Government set the framework for the development of Government policy. The co-ordination of different kinds of policy in different areas is a problem which may take some time to work through.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to the 55 hectares of land on Rottnest Island presently controlled by the Department of Defence and occupied by the Army, made up primarily of Kingston Barracks. Inasmuch as this is 3 per cent of Rottnest Island's prime area and Army exercises often extend to other parts of the island, and given that Rottnest Island is a unique Australian holiday and tourist resort, is the Minister aware that development on Rottnest in recent years has utilised most of the available land that could be used safely without endangering the island's ecology? A recent study by Dr Newman lists 92 unique features of Rottnest, the majority of which are in the flora and fauna category. The island covers only 1, 720 hectares and 250,000 people visit the island each year. In addition, about 1 ,000 pleasure craft fill the bays. Is the Minister further aware that defence facilities on Garden Island have reduced recreation areas there? Will the Army consider looking for an alternative site for its barracks and training facilities and enter into, if necessary, an exchange of land with the Western Australian Government? I remind the Minister that if there is any difficulty in finding alternative land, the Western Australian coastline extends for 12,000 kilometres and Western Australia occupies one-third of the Australian continent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is conscious of the recreational value of Rottnest Island to the people of Western Australia. The three Western Australian Ministers in this Government are fairly frequent holiday makers-that is, when we get holidays-on the island. I understand that the Army has had informal consultations about and is shortly to receive a briefing on the plans being developed by the Western Australian authorities for further tourist use of Rottnest Island. The Commonwealth Government will be happy to look at any proposals for the development of the island put forward by the Western Australian Government in the light of the consultations with the Army which will take place.

—Has the attention of the Leader of the Government in the Senate been drawn to the findings of a survey by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Bank of New South Wales? Does the survey conclude that the Australian economy is facing its most difficult time since 1974? Does it further anticipate a dramatic increase in unemployment this year despite the fact that the latest unemployment figures are the highest on record? Does the survey show that almost a quarter of the firms that responded propose to reduce their work force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press reports of the survey. Indeed, I have attempted to find time to read the survey in detail; I have not done so. I understand that the two bodies have looked at the world outside and have noted the recession in overseas countries and its impact upon trade in this country. They have noted also the upsurge in wage claims in this country together with industrial strikes and have, therefore, foreshadowed particular difficulties in the months and year ahead. It is, I think, interesting that the comparison made should be that the situation is more difficult now than at any other time since 1974. It is well to remember that 1974 was a tragic time for the people of Australia under the Whitlam Government. The fact of the matter is that there is- -
—Can't you change the record?

—No, I will never cease to remind the people of Australia of the disastrous record of the Whitlam Government. I will never cease to remind the Australian Labor Party that in the last three Federal elections the Labor Party has been kept firmly in Opposition because the people of Australia have elected to support the proven view that the Fraser Government is the best manager of this economy. The fact is that there is a significant recession overseas. Nevertheless, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has indicated that Australia's growth will be significantly more than the average growth of countries overseas. It attributes that in its reports to good, sound, economic management.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the Victorian Institute of Marine Science is, with very limited funds, undertaking a most important multifaceted study of Bass Strait and has received the co-operation of a variety of government operated and private sector vessels to assist in the study? Is the cost of suitable research vessels a major cost and an impediment to the study? Is it a further fact that VIMS has negotiated for a fully equipped research ship owned by the Taiwan Fisheries Research Institute, which is on its way back from research work in Antarctic waters, to be available for one month's research in Bass Strait at no cost and a saving of the order of half a million dollars?

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a further fact that the ship and VIMS have been awaiting approval and that our bureaucracy, involving a variety of departments, appears incapable of resolving the matter with sufficient expedition for VIMS and the Bass Strait study to take advantage of the situation? Bearing in mind that the ship has been waiting at sea, stooging around now for nearly two weeks, will the Minister endeavour to ensure, so that we do not lose by default of decision, that the matter is resolved today before the ship continues on its way back home to Taiwan without having done any of the work which could be done for nothing in the interests of Victoria, Tasmania and Australia as a whole, in the study of Bass Strait?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, of course, of the work of VIMS, particularly its Bass Strait study. It is true that in any of these marine studies the key cost is the cost of the vessel-its charter, its purchase or its operation. I am not aware of the Taiwan proposal. In view of the information that Senator Peter Rae has provided, whilst I cannot assert at this moment the factual nature of the situation, I will take this as a matter of some urgency and have it looked at immediately.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I remind honourable senators that today they received a letter from the South African Embassy asking for the co-operation of our peoples who are 'derived largely from common stock'. That is a crudely racist plea and one that is utterly untrue, unless one excludes the 20 million black and coloured Africans from the peoples of South Africa. Lest the plea be taken up by certain sympathetic parliamentarians in this place, I ask: Did the South African Government purport to confer independent status on a fourth tribal homeland called the Ciskei in early December 1981? Did the world community, including Australia, refuse to recognise Bantustan as an independent state? Did a group of some 20 Government back benchers send a congratulatory message to the Chief Minister of the Ciskei-Bantustan? Did the Australian Government disassociate itself from and repudiate this usurping and subversion of Australia's foreign policy? If not, will the Government now do so? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer the matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a response.

—My question is ad- dressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and follows closely a question asked earlier of the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Premier said last week that the base for tax sharing should be by way of personal income tax and not total taxation as it is now? Therefore, if we were wedded purely to personal income tax the States would suffer. More recently the link to full taxation has been made. It appeared that that would be a more logical basis , for the reason, as I have said, that the States would benefit in exactly the proportion that the Commonwealth does. I have not seen the Western Australian Premier's statement. I will seek it out and have it put under study.

—I have a supplementary question. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs obtain for the Senate an analysis of contributions by various countries, including Australia, to the Third World countries during the last five years, excluding the cost of arms supplied by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and its satellites?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION: STAFF CEILINGS

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. By way of information I refer the Minister to Senator Chaney's excellent answer yesterday to Senator Siddons' question on industrial relations. In his reply, Senator Chaney said:

QUESTION.PARA: I remind the Senate that the basic proposals which the Government has indicated it is putting forward relate to the question of whether a man can be forced to join a trade union if he is to have a job . . .

Those are sentiments with which I fully concur. I ask: Since the Government is prepared to support the concept that a person cannot be forced to join a union to get a job, will the Government similarly legislate so that a person does not have to join a union to get an education or a degree? Would the Minister not agree that unless compulsory student union fees are abolished the Government is guilty of having double standards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, with Senator MacGibbon, commend the principle of voluntary unionism, the right of choice of a person to join or not to join an association. The Government agrees that no student in the pursuit of education should be forced to join a students union. Indeed, the Government has made strenuous endeavours, particularly in the areas in which it has authority-that is, in the Australian Capital Territory-to ensure that this is so. The Government has also, through its Ministry of Education, invited the States to ensure that this should be so.
—And failed.

—And failed. The fact is that certain States, of course, will not go along with our endeavours. Western Australia made a valiant attempt at doing so, but the universities and colleges are, constitutionally, under State law. The rules, therefore, under which the institutions are set up are provided by State law. It is a matter for the States entirely to ensure that there is no duress upon students to join unions. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Many recommendations in that report are under study by the Government. In fact, the whole report is under study by the Government. I do not think it would be argued that what was done last week was a direct response to that report. These matters were able to be covered by the policy that we announced last week.

ANSWER.PARA: Where there is breakdown of family through an inability to continue in its own home, there is considerable cost to the social welfare system, as there is for breakdown in family relationships generally. A very large number of people become social welfare beneficiaries with dissolution of marriage in the Family Court. There would be those who, as a result of breakdown of marriage, would use many of the services of a welfare nature that are provided in the community. I do not know that any particular figure can be placed on social welfare usage as a direct result of an inability to continue with the home ownership which a family may have embarked upon some time before. There is no information that I could undertake to provide on the last part of the honourable senator's question . However, I will ask whether there is anything that could be directly related to the question and, if so, I will see that the information is provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Education to the Tertiary Education Assistance scheme. Is it true that to benefit in the 1982 year a student has only one more week to submit an application and that, at this stage, only 38 per cent of tertiary students seem to be eligible this year, a lower proportion than in preceding years. Will the Government reaffirm the objectives of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme by giving, at this time of receiving Budget submissions, careful and sympathetic consideration to increases in the value and accessibility of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme so as to benefit Australia's students and to make up for losses through inflation? Finally, does the Government confirm that, second only to the most deserving case of increasing the value of Commonwealth post-graduate awards, TEAS presents the most pressing instance of needing increased support in the area of the Commonwealth's program of student assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very familiar with TEAS and its general objectives . I am not aware that the timetable for applications is such that there is only one more week in which to lodge applications and that a low percentage of applications have been made. I will direct the attention of the Minister for Education to that aspect as a matter of urgency to ensure that no hardship is imposed upon students. The objectives of TEAS are well known. TEAS is aimed at helping needy students to gain a tertiary education, and it has worked well. Indeed, over the years the Fraser Government has made significant increases in TEAS. As Minister for Education I was able, in the second year of my ministry, to rectify some of the grave faults that the previous Labor Government had brought about. I will direct the rest of the question to the attention of the Minister for Education and ask him to study it.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he is aware of a recent statement by the president of a major aluminium producer, Mitsui Alumina Co. Ltd of Tokyo, that the company has developed a technology to smelt aluminium by a method other than electrolysis and that a pilot plant will be built next year. Is he aware that the new process would dramatically reduce the need for electric power in aluminium production and substantially reduce the cost of the metal; further, that not only bauxite ore, but also other materials containing alumina, such as clay and shale, could be used? Will the Minister ask his Department to investigate claims that the new process will be at the major production stage within a decade, the same time span as the proposed new hydro- electric development in South West Tasmania? Is it not a fact that if this new technology fulfils the promise its promoters believe it has, this must profoundly affect all areas of industry, since aluminium might well then compete with steel as a raw material? In particular, what implications does the Minister see for proposed new electricity power generation plants in Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales designed mainly to meet the requirements of making aluminium by the Bayer electrolysis process? Is it not a fact that if the Mitsui process develops successfully, all these proposals, if carried into reality, will amount to enormously expensive white elephants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that alumina smelting is very hungry in its appetite for electricity. It has been suggested that in this decade we hope to increase electric power generation throughout Australia by some 90 or perhaps 100 per cent and that, of that increment, up to 30 per cent could be used for smelting alumina. That would be on the basis that whereas today we produce approximately 280,000 tonnes of the metal annually, by the end of the decade we would be producing two million tonnes annually. Perhaps those figures will be a little lower over the decade as a result of the world recession. As to the latter part of the question, it is true that alumina smelting is energy hungry. I am aware of reports on the Mitsui development. This is still in the experimental demonstration phase.

ANSWER.PARA: I will describe the process. Aluminium bearing materials are crushed and mixed with coal to form a briquette which is then burned in a blast furnace at about 2 ,000 degrees centigrade. Lead sprayed on the resultant compound of alumina, iron and silicon changes the mix to an aluminium-lead alloy. Lead is drawn off under vacuum, leaving aluminium. The importance of the process is that it uses little, if any, electricity, relying on a blast furnace rather than on an electrolytic process; it has low labour costs, mainly as a result of its dispensing with the intermediate process of alumina production; and it can utilise low grade bauxite deposits available in Japan, Korea and China. Therefore this process would have profound effects.

As I said, the process is in an experimental and demonstration phase. It has not been proved on a commercial scale. Mitsui has cautioned against alarm amongst owners of new and prospective smelters using existing technology, stating that commercial use of the new process is 10 years off. The Mitsui process is a logical development of higher energy costs and the energy intensiveness of the Bayer and Hall-Heroult processes which are the current technologies used to tranform bauxite to alumina and alumina to the metal. The Mitsui process is one of a number of new processes being investigated throughout the world. The recent expansion in the aluminium industry in Australia has been based on the latest commercially available technology. Those smelters will take advantage of recently developed technology relating to pot design, anode manufacture, control of airborne emissions from the pot-line and reduced electricity consumption in the smelting process. Of course, we will keep the whole of the development under close scrutiny. It would be of major benefit to the world should there be such a breakthrough. Any excess electric power generation which Australia may then have could be put to very good use indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers to Australian representation at the United Nations and at other international forums. I am sure the advice of the National Women's Advisory Council would be helpful to him and would be taken into account by him as it is by many other members of the Government in forming delegations or policies on a whole variety of matters. As far as the value of Australia's briefing and assistance to delegates at that sort of conference and staffing arrangements are concerned, again I feel sure that the Minister for Foreign Affairs would see that Australia's representatives at conferences are suitably briefed. If it is a matter of rearranging the duties of staff within his department, I am sure that that is done from time to time when important conferences are held. Therefore, could the Minister advise the Senate what progress has been made in implementing the court's decision?

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Has his Department had any discussions or negotiations with the Electricity Trust of South Australia and CSR Ltd in respect of brown coal reserves at Sedan near Mannum in South Australia? If so, what is the extent and quality of the reserves? When is it anticipated that a power station will be constructed, and at what cost? Finally, has he had any request from the South Australian Government for financial assistance to construct the power station? If so, what amount was sought?

The discovery of coal in exploitable quantities and quality would, of course, alter very considerably the industrial potential of South Australia. For one thing it would ease the use of natural gas in electricity generation. A number of explorations have yielded evidence of brown and black coal deposits. I am not aware of specific discussions between the Electricity Trust of South Australia, CSR and my Department on the exploitation of coal. There are continuous researches on the use of coal in South Australia, but I will take that aspect on board.

ANSWER.PARA: As I say, it would be very significant if coal-fired power stations could be developed economically in South Australia. I regard that as a very serious and important matter. I have no knowledge of any approach by the South Australian Government for loan funds to develop such a coal-fired power station. I cannot recollect any such approach. I believe that none was made. If it was made it would have been under infrastructure financing. My instinct is that the maiden request was for the northern power station which is the primary one at this moment. Just in case there has been any approach that I do not know of I will ask the Department to put that matter on inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware that overseas visitors to Australia arriving at Brisbane Airport can be delayed for up to 3 1/2 hours before clearing Immigration and Customs? As tourism is important to the economy of my State and Australia as a whole, will the Minister investigate this matter with a view to alleviating this inconvenience to tourists visiting Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the importance of tourism to all States of Australia, not least the State of Queensland, which Senator Bonner represents. I am aware that visitors arriving often create high peak demand for services and that some of the procedures which need to be satisfied-the clearing of Customs and other procedures-put a very high call upon staff, often for very short periods. He would want to ensure for those who visit Australia, to add to its attractiveness as a tourist country, that these problems are overcome. I am sure that he would want to know more about the problems to which Senator Bonner referred. I would be grateful for any extra detail that Senator Bonner could give to me. I undertake to pass that information on to Mr Newman for his attention.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Is it a fact that the Australian Bureau of Statistics definition of average weekly earnings is about to be revised to a lower, perhaps more realistic level? If this is so, did the Government take this into account when costing its housing subsidy package last week? If not, will it now revise the costing upwards?

If there is to be a periodic review of the arrangements for eligibility it would take into account movements in average weekly earnings. —I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister care to direct her attention to the second half of my question? Did the Government take into account any change in average weekly earnings when costing its housing subsidy package last week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think the figures for average weekly earnings were mentioned at some time during discussions, but I am not aware of any changes that were taken into account. I think the percentages of average weekly earnings, as they were applied to eligibility limits, were based on the most up to date figures as we know them. I could check on that matter and see whether there is any further information on it.

—I ask a question of the Minister for National Development and Energy. As it appears that petrol prices in Australia vary from about 36c a litre in South Australia to 41.5c a litre in Tasmania, with an Australian national average of about 38c a litre, can the Minister please tell me why this is so, with particular reference to Tasmania? What responsibilities are undertaken in fixing these prices by the industry, the State governments and the Federal Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The responsibility of the Federal Government lies with fixing the price of crude oil in Australia. As the Senate would know, that figure is based upon the Saudi Arabian light crude market. That price is then referred to the Commonwealth Petroleum Products Pricing Authority, which establishes a wholesale price. Indeed, as the honourable senator would know, the Commonwealth Government has a responsibility for a freight equalisation scheme which, from my recollection, compensates by up to about 0.44c a litre for any freight disability.
—Which the oil companies keep and do not pass on.

—If Senator Chipp has such evidence I would be very willing to have it and to put it under scrutiny. The fact is that retail petrol and petroleum products price fixing is a State matter; it is not a Commonwealth matter. It comes entirely under State law. The various States impose various charges. They have price fixing systems and various charges. Petrol prices vary amongst the States for a variety of reasons, the most significant being a result of differing State government attitudes to petrol price regulation and franchise fees on transport fuels.

ANSWER.PARA: At present the South Australian Government has set wholesale prices for petrol sold in that State at 3c a litre less than the maximum wholesale price found justified by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. This may largely explain the difference between wholesale prices in South Australia and Tasmania. The New South Wales Government sets both wholesale and retail prices through the New South Wales Prices Commission, the maximum wholesale price for petrol being approximately 2c a litre lower than that recommended by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. We must bear in mind that the Commonwealth authority fixes the maximum price. Maximum retail prices in New South Wales have been set at levels varying from 38c to 39.2c a litre for the major metropolitan areas and up to 39.62c a litre in other areas. Price fixation is a detailed matter on which I have some lengthy information. Perhaps after Question Time I will supplement this answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and deals with a so-called attempt by the Government to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act relating to compulsory unionism. Is the Minister not aware that it is impossible for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to award compulsory unionism under the current provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act? Is the Minister aware that the Commission can award preference only, and then only after a full hearing, after all reasonable steps have been taken by the employee organisation to recruit, where there is evidence of employer resistance or where it is in the best interests of industrial relations for the Commission so to award? Is the Minister further aware that the human rights of individual employees are fully protected by the operation of the conscientious provisions enshrined in that legislation? If the Minister is aware of all those aspects will he not agree with me that the Government's attempt to portray this piece of legislation as an attack on compulsory unionism is a con trick on the Australian public and that it will in fact open the way to those unions which now have preference in their awards to do what the Government ought to oppose, that is, resort to forcing persons to become members on the job, which is the current policy with some more militant unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very lengthy question. Yes, I am aware of the position with respect to preference which was detailed by the honourable senator. I must say that I found it rather difficult to follow the latter part of his question. I will look at it and give him a considered reply. I am sorry, but I had some difficulty in following it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I was asked about the correctness or otherwise of a statement by Mr Martin that Australia's aid program would be underspent by $100m a year. I am advised that this suggestion is simply not correct. The so- called freeze on expenditure in respect of aid funds was lifted on Friday, 19 March. All programs that have been agreed and adequately developed are proceeding. It is expected that there will be only minimal shortfalls in aid expenditure this year. These shortfalls, if they do occur, will amount to only 2 per cent or 3 per cent of the program. Arrangements have been made for any unspent funds to be carried forward to the next year without prejudice to the size of that program. Some funds have been transferred from bilateral project aid to food aid because of difficulties being experienced by Australian Development Assistance Bureau staff in adequately assessing some proposals in sufficient time for them to be implemented this year. The Government regrets that Mr Martin has, however unwittingly, misled the public on this issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Walters asked me a question relating to the Commonwealth Schools Commission program on the education of girls. I am advised that the Commonwealth Schools Commission's working party on the education of girls was established in October 1981 to provide advice to the Commission on the allocation of the special projects program grants and also to advise about issues relating to the education of girls which were identified by the Commission in its report for the 1982-84 triennium. These issues include: How to teach mathematics and science in ways which encourage more girls to pursue them with confidence and success; how to devise and teach commercial, trade and home economics management courses in ways which are equally relevant to boys and girls; how to address some of the specific educational problems that arise from traditional social attitudes in some ethnic minority groups; how to identify and provide appropriate activities for gifted and talented girls, and the more general issue of the impact of social and technological change on the factors affecting girls' curriculum choices and employment prospects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to the answer I gave to Senator Archer' s question on the variations of petrol prices between States. Another reason for price differentials among States is the varying levels of franchise fees imposed by them. At present Victoria imposes a fee of 2.05c per litre on premium petrol; South Australia imposes 1.50c per litre; Western Australia imposes 1.60c per litre; Tasmania imposes 1.57c per litre; and two States do not impose a fee. In addition, some States, but not South Australia, impose low lead controls and this cost adds to the price of petrol. In Tasmania it means a further 0.07c per litre. Prices in Tasmania also include an outport differential of 0.11c per litre which does not apply to mainland capitals. If there is further information which I can give the honourable senator, I will be happy to do so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT: GOVERNMENT FUNDING

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yesterday Senator Watson asked me a question concerning industrial research and development funding. I undertook to provide further information in response to it. I now have a response from the Minister concerned. It is a page and a half in length and contains many figures. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

It is not true that the Federal Government has slashed finance for industrial research and development. There has, however, been a revision of the estimated amounts required to discharge funding obligations this financial year in respect of commencement grants, project grants and public interest projects.

Of the 1981-82 Budget appropriation for commencement grants of $10.5m, it is now estimated that some $9.5m only will be expended this financial year. I emphasise that this revision to the estimates entails no change in Government policy. Companies which are eligible to receive commencement grants under the Industrial Research and Development Grants Act will receive their entitlements.

In respect of project grants, an amount of $32.68m was appropriated in the 1981-82 Budget. The bulk of this amount was appropriated to meet financial obligations under existing agreements with firms that were expected at that time to fall due for payment in 1981-82. It is currently estimated that an amount of $11.18m will not now be required this financial year to meet such project grant funding obligations as a result of lower-than-expected claims from firms for advance payments and unexpected delays by firms in progressing projects. Again I emphasise that any firm which is entitled to receive funds under an existing project grant agreement with the Australian Industrial Research and Development Board will receive its entitlements. Obligations which were previously expected to be discharged this financial year will now require funding in 1982-83 or later financial years.

In respect of public interest projects, some genuine savings will be achieved this financial year against the Budget appropriation as part of the Government' s vigorous efforts to contain expenditures. Of the $6.0m appropriated for public interest projects in the 1981-82 Budget an amount of $3.55m is not now expected to be expended this financial year, although some of this funding will be required in future years. Again, any firm entitled to receive funding for a public interest project under an existing agreement will receive its entitlements.
