QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTRICITY SUPPLY SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate yesterday passed a Bill to amend the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Act 1962 to enable emergency powers to be given to the Minister for the Capital Territory ( Mr Hodgman) so that in the event of a threatened disruption to supply of electricity to the Australian Capital Territory he can take steps to regulate it . I think it is reasonable that this matter should be discussed so that the people of the Australian Capital Territory and others affected by the situation in New South Wales can know why the supply of electricity is at risk and why they are in the situation in which they are now placed. They are also entitled to ask how long they can expect it to continue. Some suggestions have been that the problem will last for about five years. Mr Wran has said it will last for about one year. This warrants looking a little closer at Mr Wran's statement which was reported in the Daily Telegraph of 2 February this year. The Daily Telegraph stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Wran admitted the electricity system was so crippled at present that power supplies would be on a knife-edge for several months.
And he said he could give no guarantee that there would be no blackouts this winter.
The Daily Telegraph continued:
'But we will beat it-there's no doubt about that,' he said.
'I sincerely believe that, given co-operation from the unions and public, we will see the problem through this winter.

I think, given what has happened in the last couple of weeks, one can question how seriously we can take his pious hope that there will be co-operation from the unions. In the Australian Capital Territory, of course, we have seen that there has been co-operation from the public. We are entitled also to look at the actual capacity of New South Wales to meet its commitments to its own citizens and to the Australian Capital Territory. There is a capacity of production inside New South Wales of 8,236 megawatt hours and the Snowy Mountains Hydro- Electric Authority has a capacity of 2,200 megawatt hours-a total of 10,436 megawatt hours. The summer peak demand is usually about 5,000 megawatt hours; in the winter of 1981 it was about 8,000 megawatt hours and in 1982 it is expected that it will be about 8,500 megawatt hours. From those figures it can be seen that the capacity to produce is approximately 30 per cent more than the demand.

I think the people of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory are entitled to expect that supply will meet demand. Why is it then that they are faced with power cuts? Why is it that the system which exists in New South Wales cannot cope with the demand? Of course, we are not told much about that. There is a fair amount of secrecy about what is the cause of the breakdowns in the New South Wales system. I am sure that somebody must know the answer. The situation now is that there are so many plants out of service that other plants cannot be stopped for the regular maintenance that they will need. One can, perhaps, predict that as this year passes the situation will get worse instead of better. The Sydney Morning Herald this morning produced some figures which set this out quite clearly. The article indicated:
Ten out of 28 generating units were out of action with faults, and the stations could produce only 33 per cent of their combined capacity . . .

The Liddell station which has four major 500 megawatt units with an output of 2, 000 megawatts produced none yesterday-the four units are all down. The Vales Point power station with six units had three not working and produced only 806 megawatts out of 2,195 megawatts. So, it goes on. A total of only 3,100 megawatts was produced from a total capacity of 8,100 megawatts.

Of course, steps are being taken to overcome this. Emergency equipment is being activated and 12 gas turbine generator units are being installed at four centres -Port Kembla, Bunnerong, just north of the Eraring power station and Koolthan in the north of New South Wales, where four units are being installed. In addition, of course, efforts are being made to bring the 660 megawatt Eraring power station on line. That, of course, also has been plagued by industrial strife and is running late. The four Liddell power units are also running late as a result of industrial strife and will not be coming into service again as soon as had been predicted. However, even if units of 660 megawatts were commissioned every six months that would only keep up with the expanding demand in New South Wales. The other intersting factor, of course, is that it seems to be the newest plants that are breaking down, not the oldest ones. The oldest ones are now being rushed into service. No doubt their maintenance has been of about the same standard as the maintenance of the newer units. So I think we can anticipate that they will prove to be unreliable and cause further problems.

It is worth having a brief look at the capital costs. I think it is reasonable to compare New South Wales and Queensland given that they are the major black coal producers. In 1975-76 there was an increase of 8.8 per cent in New South Wales and 13.9 per cent in Queensland. The following year showed an increase of 9.7 per cent in New South Wales and 12.4 per cent in Queensland. The next year showed an increase of 9.5 per cent in New South Wales and 12 per cent in Queensland. In 1978-79 the increase was 10.5 per cent in New South Wales and 10. 1 per cent in Queensland. The increase in Queensland was a little lower that year. In 1979-80 the figure was 11.8 per cent in New South Wales and 19.4 per cent in Queensland. New South Wales has had the full infrastructure borrowing requirements met by the Federal Government. In 1981-82 the amount was slightly lower but it was still sufficient to allow the full allocation by the New South Wales Government for its electricity program.

We come then to the question of maintenance of this expensive and valuable equipment. It is in this area that gross mismanagement has really occurred. The Sydney Morning Herald of 30 January 1982 had an interesting article which said:
Power black-outs for householders and industry in N.S.W. this winter are now virtually inevitable, Electricity Commission engineers said yesterday.
Of course, when one refers to New South Wales in this regard one includes the Australian Capital Territory as well. The article continues:
The situation is so critical that it will require only a large generating unit to fail in the winter peak, and load-shedding will have to occur.

According to the newspaper the engineer said that for three years the Commission had been banking up massive problems by allowing the program of annual plant maintenance to fall progressively further behind. He said:

For 2 1/2 to three years the commission has refused to allow the annual four- weekly overhaul of the four 500-megawatt units at Liddell power station, which have the capacity to produce 25 per cent of the State's power.

At that time three of those units were out and the fourth one is out now also. That is the situation with respect to the maintenance of these units. The difference between the Liddell units and those elsewhere is that in the United Kingdom the same units are subjected to regular preventive maintenance. The four Liddell units were commissioned in 1972-73. They were made and installed by the British General Electric organisation. There are 12 similar units operating in the United Kingdom which are aged from eight to 15 years. But those units have not had the same problems. Design faults are now blamed for the troubles at Liddell. But given that they have been in operation for 60,000 hours I certainly would take a bit of convincing that the problems now could be because of a design fault.

With the 30 per cent capacity available in excess of demand there can be no excuse for not having had regular maintenance of the power plants in New South Wales. It should have been quite simple to have organised a program for maintenance that enabled regular checks to be made so that the present situation could not occur. The only other conclusion one can come to is that for some reason the funds have not been made available. Of course, the fact is that the New South Wales Government has run down the financial reserves of its statutory authorities, affecting this one and probably others. The Premier of New South Wales is recorded in the New South Wales parliamentary Hansard on 9 March 1982 as making a statement that I find quite quaint. He said:
The Government has pursued a deliberate policy of running down its cash reserves in accordance with proper accounting procedures.

I do not know what Mr Wran understands as proper accounting procedures but for myself a rundown of cash balances indicates that I do not have enough resources to do what I might like to do. I suspect that the same situation applies in New South Wales. He has run down his resources and has run down the ability to maintain the Liddell and other power generators. The New South Wales Government seeks to blame and mislead on this issue. For a while it had us believe that the problem was caused by drought in the Monaro and that the Snowy Mountains scheme was at fault. The Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority has operated within its design parameters, supplying peak load to New South Wales. It is not designed as a base load unit. We would not want it changed for that purpose either because presumably the same sort of thing could happen in the Snowy as has happened in New South Wales if the equipment is overloaded, misused or is not properly maintained. The real issue is the Wran Government's inability to handle industrial relations with respect to the power industry. This has caused delayed construction and disruption to what maintenance has been done. Despite the impossibility of meeting the maintenance requirements-not to mention the backlog-there is now the introduction of a 35-hour working week.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a point of order. This point of order was brought to my notice about a couple of weeks ago by the Government Whip. It is in respect of Standing Order No. 406 which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall read his-
And I presume 'her'-
speech.
I submit that the honourable senator is reading her speech. I ask that you rule this practice out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.
—I want to quote from a comment of the Premier of New South Wales with respect to the bringing in of the 37 1/2-hour week for power workers in New South Wales. At the time he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This will mean increased productivity and no blackouts.

Given the problems that we have had since June of last year it can be small comfort to workers and industry in New South Wales that there is now a 35-hour week. Of course, there are demands for more pay as well. We are faced with a small group of workers who are quite happy to hold the rest of the work force to ransom-a group of workers who, in fact, receive considerably more pay than most of those who were stood down this week. Notwithstanding that, they are prepared to proceed. An article appeared in today's Australian newspaper which I will not read in full but which is worth noting. It said:

The New South Wales power crisis threatens the jugular of the multi-million dollar coal export industry at the port of Newcastle designed to handle a constant stream of valuable shipments to Japan and other countries. The whole of this country is suffering as a result of these problems in New South Wales.

Looking back a little, there have been a lot of interesting statements made which one would like to quote but cannot do so in the time available. The New South Wales Hansard of 6 March 1981 tells us that the Premier assured the people of his State:
There is no truth in the assertion that it will be necessary to ration electricity. There is no reason for blackouts to occur.

But, as we know, there were problems in June and December of that year. Recently the Premier changed tack a little and said that it is the people using too much power who are really to blame. At the same time, of course, he has been busily trying to attract to New South Wales the power-hungry aluminium industry and has promised it cheap and reliable power. It may be cheap but it certainly is not now reliable. As a result of this many Australians face a very bleak winter indeed. It is clear that the Labor Government cannot run an essential government service. The proof of this is the fact it has now embarked on a $1m public relations 'campaign', if that is what one could call it. One of the newspapers indicated that it was more like a mealy-mouthed word for being brain washed. Perhaps 'reprogrammed' is a better word. An amount of $1m is being spent on an advertising program in order to try to make the consumer believe that he is at fault and should feel guilty. But that is not so. It is the Government of New South Wales which should be feeling very guilty indeed about the cuts that have been imposed. During the 1981 State election-some of Mr Wran's comments bear looking at in that light-in his policy speech with respect to power he said:
To grasp the opportunities and to meet the challenges of such massive new development, we have embarked upon the biggest power generation program in the history of Australia.
We are determined that the needs of industry shall be met.
We are equally determined to protect the householders, the ordinary domestic consumers of electricity.
New South Wales has the cheapest electricity to householders in Australia.
We are going to keep it that way.
We intend that the Government itself shall have both control over and responsibility for the price of electricity to domestic consumers in New South Wales.

He went on to say again that he would ensure that New South Wales domestic consumers continue to enjoy the cheapest electricity in Australia. It may be the cheapest electricity in Australia but it is not exactly available. It is a bit like having one item on sale as a special and attempting to attract customers into a store on that basis. The real cost is to industry, to commerce and to the workers who have been stood down and can be expected to be stood down again. The Australian today states:
Power zoning in New South Wales will end at midnight tonight if vital generating plant at Vales Point in the Hunter Valley is repaired and operating on schedule today.
But the New South Minister for Energy, Mr Landa, could give no guarantee that zoning would not be reintroduced next week and that unscheduled blackouts would not occur.

Of course, he cannot give any guarantee of that because he knows that he cannot have any influence with the power unions in New South Wales, which will go on strike when it suits them, no matter what the cost to the State, to Australia and to the workers who are losing income as a result.

It is worth having a look at the actual costs. Without doubt New South Wales is the most industrialised State and the impact is great indeed. Shutting down one day a week indicates a loss of working hours ten times as great as the number lost in New South Wales through industrial disputes; and there have been plenty of them. The actual loss of wages to a worker is $44 net per week of his disposable income. That is a considerable amount to any man in that situation. There is loss of income from pay-as-you-earn tax system to the Federal Government. The whole economy is affected by loss of sales, loss of profits and loss of employment opportunities. But workers in this small group of workers do not care about that. The New South Wales Government has provided them with an environment in which they can hold the community to ransom. The Hobart Mercury of 23 March states:
The power crisis is compounded by the Government, which prides itself on having enlightened industrial relations policy, losing control of key unions in the power industry.
The same editorial states further:
The power crisis is not, however, the sole fault of recalcitrant unions either. It seems to be more a combination of planning and policy mistakes.

There can be no doubt what the problems in New South Wales are. The pity of it is that so many families in New South Wales will suffer loss of income as a result. The community of the Australian Capital Territory will suffer as a result and, New South Wales being, as I said, the largest industrialised State, the whole of Australia will suffer as a result.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTRICITY SUPPLY SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear Senator Reid's speech about the causes, the nature and the consequences of the crisis in the New South Wales electricity system. I am very glad, if I may say so, that Senator Reid has finally got her act together on that topic. I recall the next Premier of Victoria, John Cain, saying last week that the Liberal Government in Victoria could not even count. The Liberal Government in Canberra cannot even get its act together on what aspects of a most unfortunate situation in New South Wales it seeks to exploit for political purposes because we have had three--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am being somewhat maligned or misrepresented. There are a dozen ways of expressing this particular situation so that one does not come to the same answer that it is the New South Wales Government that is at fault.
—There is no point of order.

—The topic of the debate which Senator Reid wanted to introduce into the Senate today has been redrafted three times. The first topic was:'The crisis in the New South Wales electricity supply; its causes, its nature and its consequences'. Half an hour later the subject had changed to: 'The effect on the Australian Capital Territory of the crisis in the New South Wales electricity supply system; its causes, its nature and its consequences'. Finally, the third version to which I believe Senator Reid sought to address herself-although in fact she spoke to No. 1-was: 'The effect on Australia of the crisis in the New South Wales electricity supply system; its causes, its nature and its consequences'.
—The Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales are part of Australia.

—As Senator Martin says, they are part of Australia-nine out of ten for geography! I do not know whether this is an example of the Liberal Government's new federalism in action-the sort of co-operative federalism about which we have heard so much-but Senator Reid is a senator in a national parliament which has for a long time, under Liberal governments, refused to give any lead on the rational allocation of resources in this country and which has refused, in spite of numerous invitations, to give any lead at a national level on the powers, structures and activities of the electricity generating authorities in the various States. The effects of these policies in the long term are being felt in New South Wales at the moment. They were felt in my own State of Victoria last winter and will be felt again this winter. Of course, this matter of public importance is a somewhat frenetic attempt to save the Victorian Government and to suggest that Labor administrations in particular States are defective in some way and that, therefore, the people of Victoria should think twice about electing a Labor government in that State. So the real subject-three were suggested-is how to save Lindsay Thompson and in so doing how to save Malcolm Fraser--
—And to save Victoria.

—The two issues, as Senator Lewis, an interjecting senator from Victoria, knows full well, are inextricably bound up one with the other. If Lindsay Thomspson hits the deck, Malcolm Fraser will be next and perhaps his senator from Warrnambool will go with him. That is a prospect which arouses a lot of static electricity in the breast of Senator Lewis. That concerns him a great deal. What this Government knows, reeling as it is from the Lowe by- election result, is that the loss in Victoria of the Liberal Government will open the floodgates. Already we find Sir Phillip Lynch preparing to defect-the classic example of a politician who senses which way the wind is blowing and is very astute not to get caught in the draught. Sir Phillip Lynch is already distancing himself from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), deciding that he might make a run for leadership. Mr Peacock has been running for some months and is now becoming breathless. The aroma of defeat is heavy around the Prime Minister's own office, with the departure of his most loyal servant, his Press secretary of seven years, when Mr Barnett handed in his notice at the weekend.
—Is this science fiction?

—Science fiction, it may seem to the honourable senator, but I ask him to come and talk to me in about a month's time and see how much science fiction is involved in it. The Senate should understand clearly that this matter of public importance is devoted to that fourth purpose and not to the three purposes suggested in Senator Reid's three drafts. Let us look at some of the facts, first of all, in relation to the power situation in New South Wales and as it relates to the electric power situation throughout Australia. Only three weeks ago the Australian Financial Review, which ran a series of articles on the power situation in Australia, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The power crisis is not just a matter of maladministration in a single State. The whole Australian eastern seaboard is in real trouble.

Let me give honourable senators some facts in relation to that comment in the Australian Financial Review. New South Wales has had blackouts for one 24-hour period since the Wran Government, the subject of Senator Reid's vituperation, came to power six years ago. Let us look at what has happened in other States in that same six years. In Queensland in July 1981 blackouts and rationing occurred over the whole State for three days. On 4 August 1981 there were State-wide blackouts in Queensland. On 25 August 1981 there were blackouts in north Queensland. In October 1981 extensive blackouts occurred, again in north Queensland. We did not hear from Senator Reid on that occasion about the consequences of those blackouts for Australian industry nor did we hear about the poor workers of Queensland who were being put out of jobs by those blackouts . Senator Reid was strangely silent on that occasion. On 8 January 1982 again there was a total loss of electricity supply in southern Queensland.

In Victoria, between 19 May and 22 May 1981 there were major power failures. On 24 June and 25 June 1981 there were more power failures on a large scale. On 23 July 1981 there were severe restrictions and blackouts. That compares with one day in New South Wales in the last six years. When those blackouts occurred in Victoria, we did not hear from Senator Lewis about the disastrous situation that was being inflicted on the Australian people by the Victorian Government. In South Australia on 24 January 1982 there was a 20 per cent reduction in supply. There have been widespread power failures in Western Australia on four occasions between January and March 1981. On 3 June 1981 there were widespread blackouts. On 3 February 1982 there were blackouts and power restrictions. These occurred on many days on which the Senate was sitting. But we did not hear Senator Lewis chastising Sir Charles Court about that matter in Western Australia.

Of course, I have given those examples simply to illustrate a point. It is no coincidence that today has been chosen as the day on which to attack the Wran Government out of the five State governments that I have mentioned. It is not that the breasts of the honourable senators sitting opposite are weeping tears of blood for the workers of New South Wales. If they did they would do so on a totally indiscriminate basis because this problem of power and energy supply is a national problem which has affected all States in Australia at one time or another in the last two years and particularly Victoria in the last year.

So much has been made in the course of this debate that has been going on in the last few days and in answers to questions about the use of Victorian electricity by New South Wales. The fact is that under a 20-year agreement between Victoria and New South Wales power is exchanged on a half-hourly basis. Whenever one State needs more power it gets it from the other. On 28 May last year, Mr Clem Joyce, the Assistant Manager of the State Electricity Commission of Victoria wrote to the Australian newspaper. He said:

Excellent co-operation in power sharing exists between the two Commissions ( Elcom of New South Wales and SEC of Victoria). On this, as on other occasions, Elcom has provided support for Victoria without prejudicing the consumers of New South Wales.
We in Victoria have not and do not ask for more.
When the roles are reversed, and they are from time to time, the SEC provides assistance to Elcom, short of prejudicing supply to consumers in Victoria.

The Assistant Manager of the SEC went on to say that the New South Wales electricity authority should be publicly thanked for helping the State Electricity Commission of Victoria during Victoria's power crisis last year. I think he is a man, obviously, of great generosity of spirit compared with some of the senators on the Government side of the chamber.

The situation in New South Wales, which Senator Reid adverted to, derives from two things. Let me say that it is no comfort to us on this side of the chamber and it should be no comfort to any responsible Minister of the Federal Parliament to see people put out of work by the action of a minority and selfish group of trade unionists. It should be of no satisfaction to honourable senators on either side of this Parliament so see people put out of work as a result of breakdowns in electricity plants. That should be of no satisfaction whatsoever. Senator Reid thinks that selfish trade union activity has been involved. If that is a fact I would condemn it as much as she does.

Let us look at the situation which has derived in New South Wales. First of all , there has been an unprecedented and massive breakdown in the Liddell power station in the Hunter Valley. Senator Reid referred to that. The fact is that that station provides 30 per cent of the energy needs of New South Wales. Three of its four generating units have broken down with identical failures. Those failures are now subject to an inquiry by Mr George Masterman, Q.C., on behalf of the New South Wales Government. I think it is perhaps less than proper for the Senate to canvass the reasons as to why those breakdowns have occurred. Senator Reid took it upon herself to reject the view that these breakdowns may have been caused by design faults. That is a specific matter of quasi-judicial inquiry in New South Wales. Be that as it may, that is one of the options which is advanced by way of explanation of the failure at Liddell. It there had not been the failure at the Liddell power station New South Wales would have had no difficulty in meeting its power requirements.

The second problem in New South Wales to which Senator Reid adverted is industrial trouble which has delayed the repair of failed units. Of course, one can blame the unions involved for that industrial trouble. That is very easy to do. It is part of the scapegoat syndrome of Australian politics to blame everybody but yourself. If Senator Reid is accusing the Wran Government of that, I regard it as a legitimate allegation. I do not know whether it is true or not. But if Mr Wran is doing that, it is something that clearly he has learnt from the Fraser Government, because this Government does that in respect of all its failings. It seeks scapegoats in society for matters which it has promised in its electoral programs to do something about. I think one thing that cannot be avoided is that the Government senators cannot have it both ways. They cannot belong to a government which, according to the report of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which Senator Sir John Carrick quotes selectively, has no wages policy. Inevitably, there will be industrial unrest at a high level, as has occurred in Australia if one embarks on a period of government by making promises to the work force in this country about wage indexation, for example, and then promptly breaking them as did the Fraser Government. We will arrive at a situation where we will get rid of the wage indexation system and in six months the entire work force in this country will catch up with what it has lost in six years because of the failure of the Government's promise to maintain wage indexation. Thas is what has happened in Australia. That is the basic cause of all the industrial relations in this country at the moment. Those problems can be laid right at the door of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What nonsense.

—Senator Peter Baume says that it is nonsense. Perhaps we will hear from him at some stage more intelligently than we did in Question Time about this issue. There is no doubt that the problems can be laid at the door of the present Government because, as the OECD said, it has no wages policy. That is extraordinary for a government in a modern economy. Just as the SEC explains its problems, Government senators, explain theirs in terms of restrictions on borrowings by the Federal Government and on high interest rates which are in the province of the Federal Government. All these things, in a sense, stem from a crisis of national leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of future power policies in New South Wales and in spite of present difficulties, the New South Wales Government has proposals to expand the power generation capacity of that State in a dramatic way. Currently, it is undertaking the biggest power generation program in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —With blackouts.

—Yes, Senator, with blackouts. Do not get excited about cheap political points. I make the point that New South Wales is undertaking a big power generation program. One of the difficulties that that program has run into is the stubborn opposition of the Fraser Government which has imposed the most severe centralist control in the history of Australia under the so-called new federalism in relation to the States' capacity to borrow money for those sorts of developments. I make the point that the New South Wales Government has that problem to overcome.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to conclude this somewhat ecumenical survey of the electricity power situation by referring to the situation in my own State of Victoria to illustrate that this is a problem, as the Australian Financial Review points out , not of maladministration by one government but by six governments. At that stage they were not concerned with the Federal Government; they would have said so had they devoted their energies to that topic. It is a case of maladministration by six State governments and massive maladministration by seven, because the Federal Government has failed to provide any leadership in the co-ordination of power generation in Australia. The Prime Minister, Mr Lindsay Thompson, the current Premier of Victoria, and the Victorian Minister for Minerals and Energy have all claimed that since last year a considerable additional generating capacity has been produced in Victoria. That assertion is false. On 4 March this year the Australian Financial Review had this to say:
Somebody is lying about the power situation in Victoria and it is not the academic analysts.

I cannot say that in this chamber because of the Standing Orders. I will put it in these terms: Malcolm Fraser, Lindsay Thompson, and Mr Crozier are not telling the truth about the additional generating capacity in Victoria. The only new generating capacity in Victoria since the severe restrictions last June is being produced at the Yallourn W4 station. All other units were on stream prior to those restrictions and the new generating capacity amounts to 375 megawatts only . The increase in demand in Victoria exceeds the 375 megawatts now being produced at Yallourn W4. Important parts of the Newport unit in Victoria have had to be replaced. This unit is currently out of service, and it will be for six weeks. Major refurbishing at Hazelwood power station is taking place. There have been breakdowns there as well. The situation involves a national problem of great importance.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTRICITY SUPPLY SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Up to about three or four minutes ago I thought I was going to rise and speak in support of what my colleague from Victoria, the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button), had been saying. Notwithstanding his allegations, it is not my intention to commence an attack on Mr Wran. I made a note of what Senator Button said, namely, that there was no satisfaction on that side of the Parliament in seeing people put out of work by selfish trade union activity in New South Wales. I thoroughly agree with that. Let there be not the slightest doubt that fundamentally, whatever other reasons there may be, one of the major causes of the problem in New South Wales at present is the action of extremist militant union leaders who are bent on destroying this nation in order to get rid of this form of government which we hold dear. There is not the slightest doubt that their long term fundamental aim is the destruction of this nation's systems of government and administration that we hold dear.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I thought that up to about two or three minutes before the end of Senator Button's speech I would find myself in the surprising position of agreeing with much of what the honourable senator had to say. Right at the death knock he started to make statements which were just patently not true. For example, he said that under the Government's federalist policy it had deprived the States of funds. Everyone knows that during this Government's term of office since 1975-76 the States, in fact, have had available to them far more funds for all sorts of purposes than has the Federal Government.

Let us look at the Loan Council programs of the State governments for 1979-80 and 1980-81. I have the figures with me in the chamber. We see that in 1979-80 New South Wales had available to it a total of $402m in borrowings and capital grants. For 1980-81 it had available to it $422m. That represented 32.33 per cent of total borrowings available to the six States. Senator Button said that in some way or other the Federal Government has deprived the States of funds. Those figures must surely put the lie to that statement.

He then had the audacity to make some allegation that Victoria has not really increased its output of electrical power. The State Electricity Commission increased its generating capacity last year by 1,400 megawatts, which represented an increase of 35 per cent in its electrical output. Senator Button was talking about an increase in generating capacity of 375 megawatts at Yallourn. This increase has, in fact, been produced within the last five months. This again puts a lie to what Senator Button was saying. It is clear that one of the reasons why Victoria has been able to produce this extra power is because of the relative industrial peace in that State. That must surely be placed firmly as the responsibility of the current Premier of Victoria, Mr Thompson. He has demonstrated repeatedly to the people of Victoria that he is one person who knows how to keep control over the trade union movement.

The subject before the Senate is the effect on Australia of the crisis in the New South Wales electricity supply system, its causes, its nature and its consequence. I did not intend to make this a speech of criticism of Mr Wran as I have some sympathy with him at present. He is trying to govern a State in which the Electricity Commission is producing only 55 per cent of its normal output- not 55 per cent of its capacity, but 55 per cent of its normal output. That State is taking from the State of Victoria, which I proudly represent, up to 17 per cent of production. That may not be all Mr Wran's fault, as Senator Button has said. One has to agree with what the editorial in the Mercury of 23 March- that is today-had to say. It stated:
Certainly, any thoughts of using the successful record of the Wran Government as an inducement to the voters of Victoria have been dealt a body blow.

There is no doubt that the people of Victoria are aware of what the real situation is in New South Wales as a result of six years of Wran Government. Let us look at the power situation in New South Wales. In both hours and pay rates the Electricity Commission of New South Wales has been leading all workers in both the public and private sector. The people working in the power industry of New South Wales, thanks to the Wran Government, now have fewer hours to work than other people in the community and are receiving substantially higher salaries than other people in the community. What has been the result? It has been nothing but further greedy demands, as is mentioned in the Bulletin of 23 March, where it is stated:
It is those pockets of the workforce which have gained most since the demise of indexation which are clamouring the loudest.
Mr Wran is quoted as saying:
Don't tell me the Electricity Commission is an ogre as far as employers go. I know they're the opposite.
The article continues:
Yet again, it is pay relativity which is causing industrial flare-ups.

Let us look at the consequence to Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) indicated this week that if 500,000 employees in New South Wales each lose one day a week in work they and their families will suffer a loss of $22m in income each week. The loss in final output by firms in New South Wales will be some $60m each week. Reduced pay-as-you-earn income tax receipts will mean a loss of some $10m each week. Clearly, there will be further repercussions as these losses pass through the community. For example, sales will be reduced because people will have less money to spend. Profits will be reduced throughout the nation, not only in New South Wales. Because New South Wales companies will make less profit, they will be able to buy less from people in other States and the results of these reduced profits will eventually pass through the whole of the Australian community. Prices will be increased as a result of this and inevitably there will be reduced employment in the community. Unemployment in the community will rise as a result of what is happening in New South Wales at present. Let us look at the situation in my State of Victoria. The Age editorial of 23 March stated in reference to the power crisis in New South Wales:
This time, however, it would be unwise to laugh: We may be next.

I thoroughly agree with that sentence in the Age editorial. It is unwise for Victorians to laugh because they may be next, especially if Victorians elect Mr Cain as their leader at the next election. My reason for saying that is that Mr Cain has made perfectly clear that he intends to repeal the Essential Services Act, which may be quite necessary for ensuring any future power supplies in Victoria. Mr Thompson has made it clear that the legislation which he and his Government introduced has assisted him to resolve such strikes. The Essential Services Act enabled him last year to move milk and food supplies during a transport strike. The vital State Projects Act enabled the building of the Newport Power Station and thus avoided the darkness which has threatened New South Wales and the Wrongs (Public Contract) Act forced the Builders Labourers Federation to lift the bans on the Loy Yang power station which had been costing Victoria, and the nation, $4m a week. It is just these pieces of legislation which Mr Cain, the leader of the Australian Labor Party in Victoria, has indicated that if he is elected to office he will revoke. I again draw attention to the editorial opinion of the Age of 23 March 1982, which stated:

It is foolhardy for Labor to promise to repeal legislation like the Essential Services Act which could be necessary to ensure future power supplies. It claims that industrial peace in the Latrobe Valley could be guaranteed by winning the goodwill of the unions; but this has not worked in New South Wales under a Labor Government, and one must be sceptical of it working in Victoria.

That must surely be one of the most truthful of statements published in the Age editorial columns. I have just demonstrated that workers in New South Wales have been granted shorter working hours and higher pay and that they have a statutory authority which has, certainly under Mr Wran, done its level best for the workers of New South Wales. The result is disastrous for New South Wales and disastrous for the nation. I draw further attention to the editorial of the Australian of 24 March. It stated that whenever gross domestic product has begun to grow in this nation:
The more powerful unions have traditionally jumped in with unsustainable wage grabs.
Clearly that is what has happened in New South Wales. The Mercury editorial stated:
The power crisis is not, however, the sole fault of recalcitrant unions either. It seems to be more a combination of planning and policy mistakes.

I hope that the people of Australia realise the need to ensure that future governments in their States do not involve themselves in these planning and policy mistakes and that some sanity is restored to industrial relations in this nation instead of this greedy grab which goes on by the trade unionists described by Senator Button as selfish trade union leaders.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTRICITY SUPPLY SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance proposed by Senator Reid:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect on Australia of the crisis in the New South Wales electricity supply system; its causes, its nature and its consequences.

Unfortunately, we have heard very little to this point from Government speakers about the causes, nature and consequences of what is indeed a very serious situation in New South Wales. We have heard the predictable serving up of stale ideas, the attacking of trade unionism, references to greedy trade unionists and , of course, a good serve for the Wran Government. The causes of the power crisis in New South Wales go well beyond the stereotyped offerings by the Government speakers. I think the consequences have been grossly overstated by Senator Reid who has attempted to develop this matter-because it affects the Australian Capital Territory-into a sort of quasi-national crisis.

It seems that the matter of public importance debate instigated by Senator Reid is really just another attempt-a rather pathetic attempt-on the part of the Government to indulge in some political grandstanding. The Federal Government seems to think that, by indulging in such grandstanding at the expense of the citizens of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory who are suffering under power shortages, it can somehow salvage the sinking fortunes of the Thompson Government in Victoria. This week the Federal Government has already used parliamentary debates on the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Amendment Bill to engage in a mud slinging exercise directed at the New South Wales Government in a last ditch attempt to damage by association the credibility of the Australian Labor Party in Victoria.

The Government is attempting to blow the New South Wales power issue out of all proportion. I ask honourable senators to look at the way the subject of this matter of public importance developed this morning. First of all it was to be a debate about the Australian Capital Territory; then it was changed to be a debate about the New South Wales situation and the Australian Capital Territory; and now it has been changed again to include the effects of the New South Wales power shortages on the whole of Australia. The proposition that power shortages in New South Wales will directly affect the Northern Territory, Tasmania or Western Australia or any other States and Territories apart from New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, and to some extent Victoria, is a tenuous assertion. It is an overstatement that reflects the desire of Senator Reid and the Government to overdramatise the situation.

If we look at the power situation in New South Wales-which I do not deny, and which none of my colleagues deny, is a very serious situation-we see that current shortages have come about because of a number of factors. This is not simply as a result of the factor of wage demands by unions but as a result of many factors which have formed a disastrous combination. There have been mechanical breakdowns, industrial disputes and a reduction in the amount of power available from the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric scheme caused by a shortage of water. The problem of breakdown in the New South Wales power grid is one that the Wran Government faced from the time it took office. That is a point which may be unpalatable to the Federal Government. However, it is relevant that the run-down of New South Wales generating equipment began during the period of the Askin Liberal-Country Party Government in New South Wales and was continued during the succession of short-lived Liberal administrations which followed it. The Wran Government inherited a power supply which for some time had been inadequately maintained. Despite this, the Wran Government's record of maintaining power supplies to New South Wales consumers has been better than the records of either Victoria or Queensland in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are kidding, Senator. You are absolutely kidding.

—Senator Baume arrived in this chamber when the debate was at an advanced stage. Had he heard the contribution of my leader, Senator Button, he would have heard him give an account of the various power difficulties that various Liberal State Governments have faced over recent years and state that by comparison the Wran Government has not had a worse record. Despite the shocking legacy that the Wran Government inherited from a series of Liberal administrations its record of maintaining power supply to New South Wales consumers has been better, as I said, than that of either Victoria or Queensland in recent years. Prior to the planned restrictions that have taken effect this week, load shedding, under the Wran Government, amounted to one day last winter. By comparison Victoria lost about three days and Queensland has had numerous losses. Perhaps taking into account this week's losses in New South Wales, the problems in New South Wales may be almost equal to those in Victoria. Its record is certainly no worse. Anyone who read the article in the Australian Financial Review of 2 March entitled 'Why Victoria Faces Winter Power Failures' will realise that that State's power supplies are by no means assured during the coming winter.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the Victorian situation since Senator Baume seems so determined to suggest that the Wran Government is somehow in a worse situation. In Victoria the situation is as precarious as it it was last winter when restrictions occurred on two occasions. There will be no new generating capacity in Victoria until the first set comes on stream at Loy Yang in May 1984. This means that the position in winter in 1983 will be extremely serious. There can be no relief of any kind until the Loy Yang unit comes on stream. The problem in Victoria is due to mismanagement by the Victorian Liberal Government and the tight borrowing policies of the Fraser Government. The State Electricity Commission has the authority to borrow only $305m for capital works this financial year yet its capital works program to 30 June is $820m, which leaves a shortfall of $515m. That shortfall will have to be found from the SEC's internal funds. Of course this will inevitably lead to higher electricity charges.

In August last year the SEC tariff increased by 19.7 per cent, including a service charge of $18 a quarter on each Victorian household. That followed a 14. 6 per cent increase in November 1980. If it were not for the State election in Victoria on 3 April another increase of 15 per cent to 20 per cent would have occurred by now. Lindsay Thompson has been deferring that increase to prevent the complete collapse of his Government's credibility before the election. On Monday Mr Ian Cochrane of the Department of Electrical Engineering at Melbourne University released a report that predicts widespread power shortages in Victoria by the mid-1980s. Mr Cochrane says that major problems in the mid-1980s will be even worse if plant breakdowns occur. Difficulties in the natural gas delivery system would force the SEC into burning huge quantities of expensive liquid fuels to make up the deficiency. This is the legacy which the Victorian Liberal Government is going to leave to the Cain Labor Government. Yet the Minister has the hide to suggest that all is well in States other than Labor States.

Let us look at the prospects in New South Wales. The prospects for the future of power supplies in Victoria will appear brighter following a change of policy under the Cain Government. While Premier Wran has stated that power supply problems may continue in New South Wales this winter, interruptions in supply are not expected to continue past that time. New South Wales currently is in the process of a huge energy expansion program. I believe one new power station, Eraring, is coming on stream this week. After 1982 New South Wales will progressively move into a situation of excess power generation. I believe my colleague Senator McClelland will speak at some length about the future situation in New South Wales. Senator Reid chose to change the topic of this debate to the national situation and from a national perspective we should ask: What has the Federal Government's response been to all this? The only response of the Federal Government to the power crisis in New South Wales has been an attempt to make short term political capital out of it.

I now turn to the situation of my own constituents, the consumers of power in the Australian Capital Territory. Despite the melodramatic wording of Senator Reid's matter of public importance, after New South Wales the Australian Capital Territory is the only territory to be significantly affected by power shortages in New South Wales. The Australian Capital Territory gets 60 per cent of its electricity from New South Wales, the remaining 40 per cent comes from the Snowy Mountains scheme. Both sources currently have a reduced output and citizens in my electorate are suffering power rationing. The Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Amendment Bill 1982, which gave legislative effect to power rationing, passed through the Senate only last night. While it is regrettable that due to problems in New South Wales and the Snowy Mountains scheme Australian Capital Territory citizens are suffering power rationing, I think it must be pointed out that the response to this situation by the Federal Government, and in particular by the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, has been unimpressive to say the least. The response has involved just the sort of provocative non-co-operative attitude which should have been avoided .

A number of the comments that have been made in the course of this debate were to the effect that there ought to be a community concern, a national concern, on the question of power supplies. Yet the response of the Federal Government in the Australian Capital Territory has not been to work co-operatively with the New South Wales Government to achieve the best possible effects for Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales power consumers. Rather it has been one of political grandstanding. I think there has been a serious disregard of the citizens who are most directly affected and about whom I am most concerned, that is, people who live in Canberra. The extent of the Government's lack of concern about the Australian Capital Territory is demonstrated by its response to the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory on energy use, distribution and conservation in the Australian Capital Territory which was brought out in July 1981. That Committee, of which Senator Reid is chairperson, made several recommendations for power conservation in the Australian Capital Territory. It recommended:
. . . That the ACTEA conduct a survey of the generating equipment within the ACT with a view to establishing whether or not there are adequate emergency facilities within the ACT.

What has been the response of the Federal Government to these recommendations? Absolutely nothing! Even without the current New South Wales power problems the power situation in the Australian Capital Territory needs to be examined and improved. Because the Australian Capital Territory entitlement from the Snowy Mountains scheme is a fixed 607 gigawatt hours and includes no growth factor it is inevitable that the Australian Capital Territory will have to look at increasing its acquisition of power from other sources. Accordingly, the Joint Committee recommended the examination of localised emergency generation or, as a desirable alternative, measures for energy conservation. These conservation measures included incentives for energy conscious design in private buildings, attention to energy conservation and efficiency in school design and in the design and running of all Government buildings. As Senator Chipp pointed out in the Senate last night, it is nothing short of a scandal that, at a time of severe power shortages, government buildings in the Australian Capital Territory are fully lit at night. The Government has ignored all the power conservation measures suggested by the parliamentary Committee and is flouting its disregard of the situation by continuing to be extremely wasteful in an area directly under its administration.

I emphasise to honourable senators that if the Federal Government wants to have anything to say about how power supplies ought to be administered, how conservation ought to be achieved and how problems for the consumer ought to be avoided, it should say those things in relation to what it does in the Australian Capital Territory. The Federal Government and no other body is directly responsible for the administration of power supplies in the Australian Capital Territory yet here we have a situation which is far from satisfactory. The truth is that the Federal Government has made no real effort at energy conservation in the Australian Capital Territory. It has not bothered to do anything about the Joint Committee's recommendations on emergency generating capacity within the Australian Capital Territory. The Federal Government, which likes to be so critical of the Wran Government in New South Wales, has done nothing in its own area of direct responsibility, the Australian Capital Territory.

As the proportion of Australian Capital Territory power provided by the Snowy Mountains scheme dwindles the Federal Government is relying on the New South Wales Government to come good with the extra power that the Australian Capital Territory requires as its energy needs expand. Far from slinging insults at the New South Wales Government, the Minister for the Capital Territory, if he is really concerned with the best interests of Australian Capital Territory power consumers, should be approaching the New South Wales Government to seek the best deal for the Australian Capital Territory. It is Mr Hodgman's responsibility as Minister for the Capital Territory to do this. He has not done it yet. I do not know why he has not done it. I hope that Senator Reid, who represents the Government in the Australian Capital Territory, will attempt to persuade him to undertake some constructive negotiations with New South Wales so that the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory no longer have to tolerate this intolerable situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTRICITY SUPPLY SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which we are debating this afternoon is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect on Australia of the crisis in the New South Wales electricity supply system; its causes, its nature and its consequences.

Senator Button, who led for the Opposition in this debate, was very concerned-as were all those honourable senators on the Opposition side of the chamber who followed him in this debate-about the different versions of the subject proposed for debate. It does not really matter because whatever version one takes the problem is still the same and the subject of the debate virtually remains the same. What really surprises me is that the Australian Labor Party should set out in some way in this sort of discussion to defend a situation which, for very many reasons and for a number of causes, is practically indefensible. I thought Senator Button, as a Victorian, would have wanted to distance himself from such a mess by as great a margin as he possibly could. Instead, he really based his defence-if one could call it that-on a reference to power problems that have occurred in other States over other periods. Of course, none of them have been continuing problems. The New South Wales situation has been significantly bad for some 12 months or more. His reference to blackouts and power problems that had occurred in other Australian States seemed to be the measure of his defence. His logic is strange. I do not believe that he would argue that it does not really matter about Afghanistan because there are tremendous problems, great savagery and situations of considerable urgency in Vietnam, El Salvador, Poland, Angola and Uganda, Iran, Iraq and so on. Yet he said that the power situation in New South Wales is not all that serious because power problems have occurred in other places. I suppose an extension of that logic would suggest that the circumstances in Afghanistan are not terribly serious because there are circumstances just as bad in other countries.

I noted in a speech made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) some mention of the power position in New South Wales. He suggested-I believe quite rightly- that this was a major blow to the Australian nation. He followed that assertion by referring to a number of statistics which suggested that if half a million members of the New South Wales working community were out of work for a day it would mean a loss to each of them after tax of $44 a week. If the situation were to continue for three months it would mean a loss to them of something like $ 416m and a loss to revenue of some $239m over that period. That would reduce our hopes for lower taxation and so forth and put those measures a little further away.

Clearly, on statistical and economic grounds a great deal of damage has been done and is being done to the New South Wales economy in particular and to the far wider total Australian scene. I recall for the benefit of honourable senators the sorts of problems that concern the whole of Australia as a result of the disastrous power situation in New South Wales. Australia has been and I trust will always be a proud country. Australia has an enormous resource capacity to develop and to trade with many places around the world. Over the years, Australia has developed a pride which is relevant to the capacity of Australians to meet continuing and changing challenges. That sort of pride must surely be hurt and knocked around on the world scene when our country, with its massive resources for power generation, with its enormous resources in a whole range of other areas-it is probably the most productive agricultural country in the world on a per capita basis-and when so much capacity and potential is seen to be almost immobilised by, for example, union activity, more specifically actions by a small group of unionists, and by the failure perhaps of a government to take notice of reports and insistent warnings that the maintenance of its generating equipment was at such a desperately low level that the chances of maintaining a viable power system were being stretched beyond the limit.

I believe that when it is all boiled down what we have seen in New South Wales stems from industrial unrest by, on the latest figures, some 87 unionists. That figure of 87 is a bad one in the history of Australian test cricket. Indeed, I hope that Australian trade unionists also will recognise that it is a bad figure . It is a great shame that a massive number of trade unionists throughout New South Wales and elsewhere should have their livelihoods in any way threatened by the persistent activities of a mere 87 people acting in spite of the dictates of their seniors in the union field, the New South Wales Labour Council and, ultimately, the Government in New South Wales. But this is the position. In the Australian scene their action is little more than a terrorist operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have a solution to it?

—I suggest to Senator Chipp that his solution would not be applicable. I recall that only the other night he suggested that people engaged in strike action and that type of operation should, after an appropriate time, be receiving the unemployment benefits. I presume that the taxpayer should be held responsible for looking after the people who, at this stage, are very largely denying their fellow workers in New South Wales the means to carry out their jobs.
—How would your party solve it?

—Quite clearly there are proper mechanisms for solving these problems. We live by the rule of industrial law. We could solve these problems by an application of that law by those who are distinctly responsible both in the Government and in the union movement. To go beyond that is to go into a situation which, for want of a another word, I would say is at least un- Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that as recently as March 1980 it was suggested, in a report called for by the Government and produced by a Mr Newton, that tariff restructuring was an essential part of the problem relating to power in New South Wales. That report, for I know not what reason, has not been acted on. It was a report which allegedly would save a very great amount of power in New South Wales and may well have contributed significantly to solving the problems with us today, yet there has been no attempt that I can find to act upon the recommendations.

It is worth noting in this debate that the crisis is about not only the circumstances surrounding those 87 people or the circumstances of the immediate past but also a continuing situation in which there has not been any real effort to maintain the generating equipment in that State. Clearly, maintenance has been neglected, and neglected savagely and completely irresponsibly. The New South Wales Government allowed its reserves to be run down dramatically. In 1976 -78 no less than $350m of its reserves disappeared, and in 1981 alone a further $340m disappeared. Indeed, of the first amount $100m was for the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, yet that significant amount of money was diverted to other fields. There are enormous repercussions from the power situation in New South Wales today. They are repercussions which are relevant to prices, inflation and employment and all the problems responsible government must grapple with constantly if we are again to achieve the sort of potential that indeed we have achieved.

The problem in New South Wales has proved to be quite clearly poor maintenance over a significant number of years and, indeed, bad industrial relations. What a fascinating exercise it is to consider that in 1977 Mr Wran introduced the 37 1/ 2-hour week in the power industry on the grounds-indeed had they been proper grounds it would have been a reasonable and responsible move-of increased productivity. Two years later that was reduced to 35 hours a week. Since that time we have seen disaster fall around the power industry in New South Wales because of the 35-hour week and increased wages. Indeed, the wages in the power industry, as I recall, average in excess of $400 a week and range up to $42,000 a year. That level of wages is not insignificant.

TALK.START.PARA: —For blue collar workers?

—It is described as the average power worker's wage. So those wages are not insignificant. Add those wage levels to a reduction of five hours in the working week, and what do we have? We have industrial unrest. Worse still in New South Wales in the last eight or nine months there has been an increase in the cost of power, when it is available, of no less than 42 per cent. It is not really a very significant contribution to the development of a great State in a great country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid, who led this debate on behalf of the Government-this is the third draft of a matter of public importance submitted by her on the subject today-said that the only conclusion one can come to is that funds have not been made available for the effective electricity generation or maintenance in New South Wales. I might have something to say on that aspect a little later. She then took on the unions and said that Australia is faced with a small group of workers who receive much more than the average wage and salary earner. I remind her that, probably, that remark in her speech was taken from a recent statement by the Premier of New South Wales. It is all right for Senator Reid and Senator Scott to castigate and criticise the trade union movement and the Government of New South Wales for the introduction of a 35-hour-week but it is not the blue collar workers who are causing industrial trouble on this occasion; it is a handful of foremen or supervisors. The blue collar workers cannot work on the maintenance of the boilers because they do so without adequate supervision. It is all huffle and puffle for Government senators to criticise industrial relations on the part of the New South Wales Government or the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: While Senator Reid has a side swipe at the trade union movement and at the work force generally I suggest to the honourable senator from the Australian Capital Territory that she go to Sydney, speak to the responsible trade union movement, speak to the organised and disciplined trade union movement in New South Wales, speak to the trade union leaders, whether they be left wing or right wing, using the political terms that the Government is so fond of using on so many occasions . The honourable senator should find out what they are doing. They are working day and night in order to get workers back into the industry and to get the power houses on line. If the honourable senator from Canberra made a trip to Sydney and did those things I am sure she would not make such irresponsible statements.

Senator Reid then charged, tried and found the Premier of New South Wales guilty of attracting heavy industries such as the aluminium industry to New South Wales. I think she mentioned, during the course of her speech, the Hunter Valley of New South Wales. I remind Government senators that in 1979 their then Minister for National Development, Mr Newman, made a statement to Parliament on a national energy policy that had been considered and brought down by the Government. Mr Newman, on 5 April 1979, in the House of Representatives enunciated the Government's national energy policy. Among other things, he said:

Australia has abundant sources of solid fuels in the eastern States suitable for power generation. Soundly planned and timely installation of new power generating capacity is essential to facilitate the transfer of demand for energy from liquid fuels to electricity derived from solid fuels or hydro-electric resources. A ready availability of electricity generating capacity will also facilitate the establishment of new industrial development projects of a nature consistent with the Government's objectives towards mineral processing and industry policy generally.

Mr Newman then went on, but time does not permit me to read what he said in detail except to mention how, as a result of the Governments policy, it wanted to encourage the development of the aluminium industry throughout Australia. Now , because the New South Wales Government has put into effect those policies enunciated by this Government as long ago as 1979, we hear Government senators now criticising the New South Wales Government. One of the great problems has been the failure of the Government not only to lay down a policy in regard to fuels, energy and wages but also to police its policies or come up with relevant funds to implement them. As I said, three draft matters of public importance on this subject have been submitted by the Government today. I noticed that, in typically confused fashion, Government senators confined, or attempted to confine, the discussion to cause, nature and consequences. Senator Chipp, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, was quite right when he said by way of interjection to Senator Scott 'what is the solution that you offer?' Not one of the Government statements or speeches that have been proffered today in this House has come up with a solution to the problem. The Australian Labor Party is quite happy to discuss all the matters enunciated in the terms of the matter of public importance. But I would have thought that the most important matter to consider and discuss would be the solution. Although the Government apparently does not want to broach the subject, I certainly intend doing so.

Firstly, no one can deny-the labour movement does not intend to deny-that there have been and are grave problems in New South Wales with electricity development . By way of aside, I say that Government members cannot say that the New South Wales Premier has attempted in any manner, shape or form to pass the buck. The Electricity Commission of New South Wales is an independent statutory authority. Frankly, a certain amount of blame must attach to that authority. But in the last four or five years, as a result of the policies pursued by the Wran Labor Government in order to bring about reasonable employment in my State, which I have the honour to represent in this Parliament, there has been amazing industrial development. We have previously discussed matters of public importance in this chamber, for instance on the industrial development of the Hunter Valley and the effect of that development on the wine industry. I remember our erstwhile colleague the Liberal senator from New South Wales, Senator Puplick, debating the matter in this chamber just prior to his departure . There have been enormous industrial strides forward in New South Wales. One of the great problems that the Electricity Commission of New South Wales has had has been to keep pace with and ahead of those developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —But, Senator--

—Senator Baume will have an opportunity to speak in this debate if he wants to do so. He is from New South Wales and he is a Minister in this Government. He sat in the chamber at Question Time interjecting . I have only another seven minutes in which to speak. I will say what I want to say and not what he wants me to say. Senator Baume can speak in this debate or we can have another debate on the adjournment tonight. The Labor Government and organised labour in my State have always realised that there were electricity problems on the horizon. They have been criticised by Government speakers for introducing the 35-hour week. I think that in Victoria electricity workers have a 37-hour week on a promise that it will be reduced gradually to a 35-hour week.
—Who is in government there?

—The Victorian Liberal Government is in power. In Queensland, which has a National Party Government, I think some agreement has been reached between the electricity workers and the Government that a 35-hour week will be phased in. Government speakers conveniently choose to ignore the industrial relations arrangements that have been brought into effect in Victoria and Queensland and they criticise New South Wales because it has led the way. Had New South Wales not acted in the way in which it did in 1977 and again in 1979, the crisis that is now being caused by a few foremen or supervisors would probably have been much worse. Government speakers should appreciate that the responsible and organised trade union movement is working closely with the New South Wales Government to overcome the problems that are being caused to the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst honourable senators opposite blame the State Government, the New South Wales Electricity Commission, the trade union movement, the purchase of poorly functioning generators-I understand their purchase was, in the first instance, approved by the Askin Liberal Government-the poor quality of coal that has been supplied for burning and the 35-hour week, they must also face up to their own responsibilities. I have a document headed 'Major Public and Private Infrastructure Projects'. It was published by the Commonwealth Department of Industry and Commerce in March 1981. It sets out the major infrastructure projects in New South Wales and it categorises those committed and those under investigation. It defines 'committed' as follows:

'Committed'-indicates that construction is proceeding or that Government/ Company Board has decided to proceed (either authorisation of expenditure or 'in principle') and construction is expected to commence shortly. A decision to proceed, however does not guarantee that the project will be constructed on the scale or in the time frame indicated. Substantial rescheduling of projects due to changing priorities and availability of funds may occur.

This document was put out in March 1981 by the Federal Department of Industry of Commerce. That document sets out the 'committed' power stations in New South Wales. I assume they were committed and approved by the Federal Government. They include the Bayswater power station, which is about 15 miles out of Singleton, Mount Piper, which is near Lithgow, Eraring which, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who is at the table will know, is on Lake Macquarie, and Liddell at Singleton. So, according to the Federal Government's record, those power stations were in the course of coming on stream in March 1981. But what happened? About 18 months earlier, in November 1979, Mr Fraser wrote to all Premiers asking them to reassess their demands for electricity because of the oil crisis then occurring. He asked the Premiers to submit new proposals to the Federal Government for infrastructure funding. The letter that the Prime Minister wrote to the Premiers referred to the world energy situation and the opportunities for Australia, because of the rising overseas costs of oil-based power genertion as opposed to our coal-based alternative. He also, incidentally, wanted electrification of the Sydney- Melbourne rail link.

The New South Wales Government got to work and drew up plans for the boosting of its electricity generation programs. I think from recollection an additional $2,000m in Loan Council funding was requested by New South Wales. It submitted proposals for infrastructure borrowings for three power stations: Eraring near Newcastle, which is named in the document to which I have referred; Bayswater stage and stage 2 which is named in the document; and Mount Piper near Lithgow which is also named. Eraring was approved at the end of 1978 with stage 1 of the Bayswater plant. But the 1980 Loan Council meeting deferred approval for the rest of the New South Wales program, involving stage 2 of Bayswater and Mount Piper. That was a win for the Federal Treasury, but meanwhile the New South Wales Premier had entered into power commitments for the rest of the decade. The 1980 election came. What did the Prime Minister of Australia say on the subject in the Liberal Party policy speech of October 1980? He said:

Let me give you another measure of what is happening in Australia. The increase in electricity generation through the 1980's will be almost equal to that which occurred over the last thirty years. We are going to do in ten years what previous generation took thirty years to accomplish.

At the first Loan Council meeting that was held after the general election of 1980 the Federal Government refused to make the funds available to the New South Wales Government for additional electricity generation purposes. So today, as a result, the Electricity Commission of New South Wales is starved of adequate funds for the proper development of electricity generation.
