QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTRICITY SUPPLY SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance, placed on the agenda by the Liberal Party in the person of Senator Margaret Reid, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect on Australia of the crisis in the New South Wales electricity supply system; its causes, its nature and its consequences.

Sometimes I shudder at the fearful price that we pay for democracy and for free speech in this country. I think Senator Reid-I am not saying this purely for the purposes of gallantry-made a very good speech on the matter. I do not think anybody would deny that this matter is on the agenda not because there is a power shortage in New South Wales, not because of something the Wran Government has done or has not done, but simply because of an event that will occur in 10 days from now in Victoria, namely, the Victorian election. That is fair enough, I suppose. The master plan was to show that an Australian Labor Party Government in New South Wales had failed miserably in an essential exercise, that one of the erstwhile glamour boys of the Labor Party, Mr Neville Wran, its Federal President, had really fouled things up there so, therefore, people should not vote for John Cain in Victoria on Saturday week. One wonders as one sits on the sidelines as an Australian Democrat, not having any delusions that the Democrats will gain Government in Victoria on Saturday week, whether the debate this afternoon-fine though some of the speeches have been-has influenced one individual in Victoria to change his vote. I prefer-I intend this afternoon without in any way adopting a holier than thou attitude-to look at some of the real problems that can be discerned from this situation in New South Wales at the moment. This situation is not unique in Australia.

New South Wales is the most populous State in the Commonwealth. It contains nearly 40 per cent of all the country's manufacturing industry. It employs 430, 000 people and produces nearly $9,000m in revenue each year. The annual demand for electricity is greater than 8,000 megawatt hours. The State now faces a crisis, as we know, in its power generating capacity. This is just not a localised problem but one which will have massive repercussions for all Australia. We can stand up here today while the proceedings are being broadcast, and try to make political points off one another, but let us not forget the fearful lessons that are to be learned-not just because this happens to involve a State in which a Labor government is presently entrenched.

Senator Reid made a fine speech in the sense that she showed up some weaknesses in the New South Wales system. Then, x equals 0, Senator Button followed up with an equally fine political speech to show that the shortage of electricity in New South Wales now is nothing new, that States such as Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia-all governed by non-Labor governments-had far worse electricity shortages and blackouts in the same sort of period. Where does that argument get us? I think it was shown by Senator Button that the facts of the matter are that Victoria and New South Wales both have shortages from time to time. By an excellent reciprocal sharing agreement, when New South Wales is in trouble Victoria has sold it some of the Victorian electricity and vice versa. This has worked both ways very satisfactorily. We happen to be at a point of time--

TALK.START.PARA: —So it should.

—So it should, indeed. We happen to be at a point 10 days before a certain election with certain problems in a certain State. I do not want to go into the causes of the current crisis in New South Wales-to say that they are complex is oversimplifying them. There have been mechanical breakdowns and lapses in the maintenance procedures. Those have been exacerbated recently by the dismal state of industrial relations in New South Wales-a few bandid bandits , a few greedy, well paid unionists have held the State to ransom. Before we knock all trade unionists let us remember that in the mass meetings that have been held an overwhelming number of trade unionists in New South Wales have voted to return to work in a most responsible fashion. Whilst we might say that trade unionists have caused this trouble we should not say that every trade unionist is being irresponsible and therefore plunging the State into darkness. There are certain militants in the trade union movement. Senator Scott from the National Country Party also made a fine speech. He was gracious enough, when I interjected to ask what was his party's solution to industrial disputation, to admit that he had no solution.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not claiming that this is an easy problem easily fixed but at least we, the Democrats, have tried hard to put something forward. We say that every worker has an inalienable right to strike. We believe, though, that those workers in essential industries should have fewer opportunities to go into a capricious strike or to strike facetiously than people in non-essential industries. So the Democrats have put a point of view forward which we have canvassed with several trade unions. We have found them to be very receptive to the idea. Why not start with workers in the essential industries entering into a contract between the employer, whether it be private enterprise or a statutory corporation, and the employee, a contract enforceable at law? In that contract the employee in the essential industry-electricity provision is a classic case- would sign away his or her right to strike except under narrow, prescribed circumstances for a certain period; two years, three years or whatever. The State, the employer and the people could then say: 'At least in that industry the workers have signed away their right to strike. We have stability in that industry for two or three years'. One might well ask: 'Why would workers sign away their right to strike?' Because they would be offered a premium on top of their wages for so doing. That very system does work in the United States of America, in West Germany, in Switzerland and in many other countries. But here, because we have this constant confrontation between organised labour and organised management exacerbated by political intervention, we do not even get around the table to talk about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is working between the metal trades industry and the trade unions.

—I think I heard Senator Gietzelt saying to me that it is working in a small way in Australia already. If he said that, I agree with him. Why can we not extend this? Why can we not, by consultation with essential trade unions, extend this principle of agreement into the essential industries? To me that is the only way in which problems like this can be avoided. The New South Wales Government's response when it believed major blackouts were imminent was to launch into a million dollar advertising campaign to try to reduce domestic electricity consumption by 6 per cent. That was a marvellous thing to do. But the New South Wales Government did it at the wrong time for the wrong reasons. All governments ought to be spending money on conservation of energy, not just when a strike is imminent. One wonders too, as an Australian Democrat, why governments of all complexions can never find any money for any worthwhile purpose unless there is some threat to their own integrity. One wonders why this impoverished Federal Government can suddenly produce $300,000 to advertise the benefits of its new housing policy just 10 days before a Victorian election.

SPEECH.PARA: One does not blame anybody for becoming cynical. Why do we have to wait until a crisis before we make any move to become active in conservation? Energy conservation is nothing less and nothing more than the wise and efficient use of energy. It is something we should be aware of and act upon at all times. Energy conservation has the ability to be our single greatest resource of energy. We have a lot of work ahead before we can claim in Australia that we are wise and efficient users of energy. While most industrialised nations have reduced significantly the amount of energy consumed since the crisis in 1973 of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Australia has actually shown an increase. Let me be critical again of this government in New South Wales. I am not being party political. The same criticism can be levelled at every government in Australia. The chief economist of the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd, Mr John Brunner, says that there is one obvious reason why our energy consumption has risen. He stated:
We don't have a single-minded policy to reduce energy consumption.

He is right, we do not. This is because of the ridiculous and absurd proposition of precious State sovereign rights. For those who have been a Minister, or will be a Minister, one of the most pathetic and disgusting exhibitions one can experience is to chair as a Federal Minister a meeting of one's State counterparts. It is disgraceful to see the way in which these petty little people will hang on to their precious State rights at any cost, even though one may present an unanswerable case to them that in the national interest they should work as Australians, think as Australians and act as Australians. But no, we have six different energy policies, not only in relation to energy conservation but also energy itself. We have six different policies, plus one from the Federal Government, which means that Australia now is labouring under seven different energy and resource policies. The number would be eight if one wanted to add those impacted upon us by the multinationals. I would have thought that one of the things we desperately need in this country is a referendum in which the people can be asked to pass on those policies and responsibilities to a Federal government.

Tasmania, the State which consumes as much electricity per head as anywhere else in the world, has already embarked on a conservation program under Premier Holgate-I do not think he is one of the world's greatest conservationists-which he believes will be able to save 20 per cent of all domestic consumption in Tasmania. The Department of National Development and Energy, in its submission to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania, pointed to a massive problem in relation to electricity commissions and energy conservation. Let us face it; the job of electricity commissions is to increase the quantity of electricity produced and sold and to decrease the amount that people have to pay for it. This is going in exactly the wrong direction in an energy hungry world in which these precious resources are being allowed to run out. Why do we not have politicians, who do become Ministers, who are able to control their departments instead of their departments or statutory corporations controlling them?

Let me give the Senate an example. The situation is no different in New South Wales. In March 1980 a radical conservation plan was prepared by Mr J. S. Newton which recommended that conservation could save 2,500 megawatts of electricity. That is the equivalent of 42 per cent of the generating capacity of New South Wales in 1979. That report has been shelved, cleverly by the bureaucracy, because Ministers, politicians and parliaments are either too ignorant or too gutless to buck the bureaucracy concerned. The Australian Democrats believe there is a serious problem. It has nothing to do with the present crisis but all to do with the Victorian State election.

OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill amends the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to introduce charges for overseas students who will attend accredited advanced education level courses which are funded by the Commonwealth and offered at educational institutions other than universities and colleges of advanced education, for example, at colleges of technical and further education. At present, charges are imposed only on overseas students attending prescribed courses at universities and colleges of advanced education in Australia. It is intended that the extension of the charges will be applicable at the beginning of 1983.

The basis for the imposition of charges on overseas students is to recover part of the costs involved in their education in this country. These costs are being met by the Australian taxpayers. Honourable senators will recall that when the Government first introduced overseas student charges in 1979, it was emphasised that the effect of the policy would be closely monitored and reviewed.

Following a review of the overseas students policy by an inter-departmental committee last year, the Government decided to extend the overseas students charges. At the same time, the Government also decided, as part of Australia's special assistance, to meet the costs of overseas students charges from 1982 for nationals of Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific countries from its aid program for the region. The aim is to encourage more students from the area to come and study in Australia. The extension of this special aid program is consistent with our special relationship with and obligations towards Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific island countries by virtue of Australia's geographic location, historic ties and relative economic strength in the region.
The special assistance in favour of nationals of the South Pacific countries will also cover the new charges when they come into effect.

The main clauses of the Bill are: Clause 2 inserts the definition of 'declared course' into sub-section 4 (1) of the Principal Act and amends the definition of 'prescribed course' for the purposes of the Act. Its effect is that an enrolment in a 'declared course' will be subject to a charge under section 5 of the Act. Clause 3 enables regulations to be made to declare for the purposes of imposing charges, courses offered by special educational institutions other than universities and colleges of advanced education. Clause 4 inserts a new section into the Act to provide for charges to be imposed in relation to 'declared courses' in the year that follows the year during which the declaration with respect to these courses was made. It also contains transitional provisions to exempt continuing overseas students from the new charges. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill amends the Overseas Students Charge Collection Act 1979 to provide that, where the responsibility for the payment of a charge has been accepted by the Commonwealth in favour of an overseas student, the specified time limits for the payment of that charge would not apply, and a visa and temporary entry permit may be granted to that student. These two minor technical amendments to the Principal Act are designed to allow more flexibility for a Commonwealth authority to pay charges on behalf of overseas students from the South Pacific region under Australia's aid programs for this region. The Bill does not affect existing provisions in the Act with respect to special arrangements with a government of an overseas country for the discharge of liability for overseas students charges. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating an amendment proposed by the Government to the Social Services Act. The amendment seeks to deny the single rate unemployment benefit to spouses of trade unionists involved in strike action, to spouses of unemployed persons denied benefits because of the work test, and to spouses of those allegedly voluntarily unemployed or dismissed for alleged misconduct. In addition, this denial is extended to the special benefit provisions of the Act so that spouses of those who would have received special benefit, had they failed any of these conditions, also would not get it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, in support of its proposition, suggests that the taxpayers of Australia should not be responsible for the funding of strikes. In that I totally concur. I do not think anyone in this chamber or any member of the Australian public would object to that proposition. But that is not what the amendment is all about. The amendment, as I will point out shortly, is discriminatory in its application and is inconsistent with just and equitable principles of industrial relations. It will not have the desired effect but will , in fact, impose heavy burdens on the already stretched resources of voluntary agencies working in the social welfare arena.

If we analyse precisely the effect of the Government's proposed amendment to the Social Services Act we will see that the word 'involved' is a key word in any consideration of these proposals. As I mentioned at the outset, the objective of the Bill is to deny the single rate unemployment benefit to spouses of trade unionists involved in strike action. First of all, it is not the spouses who are involved and it is not necessarily their husbands or wives who are involved in the strike action. Members of a union could be involved in a dispute many miles away from the factory in which other members of the same union are working and those other members could be drastically affected.

When last I addressed myself to this particular proposal I gave the illustration-it is a practical illustration-of Geelong and Broadmeadows in Victoria. As honourable senators will no doubt be aware, large vehicle component parts and manufacturing complexes are located in those areas. I invite honourable senators to recollect that some years ago considerable hardship was experienced in the city of Geelong as a result of strike action taken in Broadmeadows by a group of trade unionists at that site. On that occasion, once the strike had occurred in Broadmeadows it created a bottleneck which enabled the company at Geelong to stand down its workers. Those workers were not involved in that strike action. They had no real say over whether the strike took place in Broadmeadows. Indeed, they attempted to have a say about that particular issue but their views were completely ignored. With this legislation the Government proposes to deny sustenance to the spouses and children of those workers who would have been stood down by the employer in Geelong, through no fault of their own. That is an extraordinary situation for the Government, which says that it is interested in the one-income family to maintain. I believe that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who is at the table, could not maintain that as a just and equitable proposition.

Let us take the current power dispute in New South Wales. If, of course, the stand-downs or strikes continued for a considerable period-in excess of a week because of the unemployment benefit requirements-this measure would deny benefits under the Social Services Act to spouses of members of a number of unions, when in fact their unions had directed them to go back to work and to do the maintenance. Their own unions have done that; a unanimous decision of the Labour Council of New South Wales was to that effect. Yet the application of this legislation would mean that the wives and children of members of the union which was directing the people back to work would be penalised. What an extraordinarily unjust situation! To my mind it shows a complete lack of understanding by the Government as to what industrial relations are all about.

On the last occasion I addressed the Senate on this particular matter I also mentioned that one could have a situation where a job was totally unsafe and the workers directly involved went out on strike and refused to go back to work until the unsafe practice or the unsafe conditions were rectified. Let us not forget that 19.2 per cent of all disputes last year were caused by what the Australian Bureau of Statistics stated were working conditions and that a large proportion of those disputes were over safety conditions. In that circumstance, where the employees had taken action to preserve life and limb, the Government would deny sustenance to their spouses and to their children because those workers had chosen to protect life and limb rather than to work in unsafe conditions. I put it to the Government that it does not understand at all the workings of the trade union movement or indeed the working conditions of employers in this area. Let the Government give to the Senate an indication of any employer or any trade union who supports this measure. I invite the Minister for Social Security to name any employer or any trade union--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will a taxpayer do?

—Or indeed any representative of the taxpayers to support what he is doing and what he is proposing. I am quite convinced that the taxpayers of Australia, once the Government is exposed on this measure, for its failure to understand the equity, will, of course, reject the Government's proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned the New South Wales electricity dispute. That dispute was, of course, generated by what could be roughly called a shop committee, a combined salaried officers' committee. That committee, of course, did not have a direct link with the unions directly involved. Of course, the dispute was made up of unionists from a number of unions. Those unionists-about 57 or 60 of them-took the action. It could have had the effect that I have described. If this Bill were passed it would have the effect, if the strike went on long enough, of wives and children being denied sustenance. It escapes me completely as to how that is reasonable and equitable. As I mentioned, it shows also that the Government does not understand that orderly industrial relations depend on representative trade unions.

Only last year the Government amended the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and took away from an individual union its right to enforce decisions concerning industrial disputes made by the properly elected bodies of those trade unions. I believe that that fosters the type of anarchy that exists in some unions throughout Australia. Rather than attempting to govern industrial relations by attacking the spouses and children of trade unionists, the Government should create an atmosphere in which the conduct and control procedures for the settlement of industrial disputes are observed. This measure flies in the face of that desirable objective. It undercuts that desirable objective.

Perhaps the Government will consider exempting a number of disputes in which workers become involved. If the Government were genuine about industrial relations, why would it not propose an inquiry into the types of disputes which would come within the ambit of the Bill which is now under consideration? For example, if the Government desires to see orderly industrial progress, why does it not exempt the disputes which are conducted in accordance with the procedures for the conduct and control of industrial disputes? I hope that the Minister will address himself to that question when he replies. Why are those particular disputes not exempted? Why are disputes about working conditions and safety conditions not exempted? According to the ABS 19.2 per cent of all disputes are caused by managerial problems. Why are those disputes not exempted from the provisions of this legislation? I feel that the only reason that the Government has introduced this legislation is to provide it with a further trigger for a double dissolution. It is the only reason that I can see behind this legislation . I cannot see any other rhyme nor reason for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not any.

—I agree with Senator Haines, there is not any. If this is the Government's tactic it does not do itself justice. It certainly does not do justice to its industrial relations and orderly industrial progress in Australia . Indeed, this, together with the proposed measures that will be introduced into the House of Representatives later this week in which the Government seeks to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, will cause disputation and might ultimately cause the downfall of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982). The objectives of the Bill are primarily to deny the single rate of unemployment benefit to spouses of trade unionists involved in strike action, to spouses of unemployed persons denied benefit under the work test and to spouses of those allegedly voluntarily unemployed or dismissed for alleged misconduct. This Bill is significant in that a social welfare Bill is being used to reduce the power of striking workers and to increase the power of employers. The Bill concentrates on the rank and file trade unionists, their spouses and their children. It concentrates on people who are already poorly off, on people who are living in isolated areas, in mining and company towns and on people with no alternative employment, particularly the wives of trade unionists. Senator Chaney, during Senator Harradine's speech, interjected and referred to the taxpayers. Are strikers not taxpayers? The way Senator Chaney interjected and the way that Senator Walters has carried on, one would think that as soon as a person is involved in an industrial dispute he or she ceases to have the rights of a taxpayer. This Government is seeking to take away the rights of people who have paid taxes all their lives and who expect to be protected and expect their wives and children to have protection.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody on the Government side of this chamber has contested Senator Grimes's figure that the total amount of money involved in this legislation is $5m. I want to talk about the taxpayers of this country. I refer the Government to some of the people whom it does not like to talk about, the tax avoiders. The tax avoidance industry is responsible for $7,000m. That is not my figure. That is a figure mentioned by the secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association, Mr Risstrom. He said that the taxes uncollected by this Government amount to $7, 000m. That is a large amount when compared with the $5m involved in this Bill. That $7 billion represents $30 a week to each household. That is the amount that this Government forgoes at present. Tax avoidance in the last financial year was up by 30 per cent. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) knows that that is the one growth industry under this Government. Since 1975 tax avoidance has increased 26 fold. It is rivalled only by the increases in inflation and unemployment that are characteristics of this Government. The report of the Commissioner of Taxation shows that the official figure for uncollected taxes amounts to $973m. That is only the tip of the iceberg. Yet the Government has not challenged Senator Grimes's total figure of 20,000 spouses out of work in a work force of 6.6 million people. These people represent 0.3 per cent of the work force. The Government is setting out to attack this minuscule number of people by means of this proposal. The figure of $993 million is acknowledged by the Commissioner of Taxation to be the official figure. On average this works out to be $43,500 for each tax bludger. These are the people the Government cannot do anything about. If one contrasts the 22,366 people who are officially in that category with the 20,000 spouses, one can see that for each tax avoider 740 wives or children could be given sustenance, as Senator Harradine has suggested, so that they would not be impoverished as a result of an industrial dispute. The figure is very small. Senator Chaney gave this away himself. In answer to a question from you, Mr Acting Deputy President, in which you were drawing attention to the small number of people involved, Senator Chaney said: ' What is all the fuss about?' Of course, we want to know what all the fuss is about. It could well be that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is about polarising Australian society.

There has been talk about triggering a double dissolution. I suggest that the Fraser Government is making a double-barrelled attack on wage and salary earners . The first barrel, which perhaps has been loaded by the Prime Minister, is the Viner company unions proposals to extend stand-downs and, by legislation, to attempt to eliminate preference to unionists. This is one barrel of the shotgun. Another example could be that the Prime Minister, from his bunker, has made Mr Viner his kamikaze Minister. He is trying to get a target. If he collapses, that is the problem in being a kamikaze or a volunteer of that type. We must look at both of these proposals at the same time because they are related. What we have before us is industrial legislation under the guise of social welfare. The Viner proposals have been rejected by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Why has an employer counsel such as George Polites said that the employers could be worse off under this legislation than when they started? Every other employers organisation knows that the Viner proposals have the stamp of fanaticism and extremism about them. Of course, the proposals themselves will change daily. With a little luck there will be enough common sense people in the employers organisation to make sure that finally they do not occur.

There is a second barrel. I am afraid that Senator Chaney has his finger on the trigger of the second barrel which is pointing at the spouses of trade unionists . This social welfare legislation will advantage the largest and most prosperous companies in Australia and perhaps in the world-companies whose attitudes to tax avoidance do not bear examination. I certainly will be looking at the position of some of these companies and drawing the attention of honourable senators to the fact that the Government is protecting some of the worst companies and attacking some of the poorest people or the people who are making this country great. The people in these isolated mining areas have, through their sweat, created the wealth that this country is so proud of.

The alternative view is that the Government is desperately trying to protect the mortally wounded Thompson Government in Victoria. This legislation is part of the subterfuge and part of the attempt to cover up the fact that that Government is haemorrhaging and will be defeated at the forthcoming election. It might be an attempt by this Government to direct attention away from the fact that the Victorian Government has failed in its pledge to the people and will soon be replaced by the Cain Government.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was critical of Industrial Relations Minister Viner for proposing a Bill to introduce company unions and to allow for automatic stand-downs in industrial disputes. I linked that with the Bill before us tonight in which it is proposed that wives of unionists will be denied welfare payments and denied sustenance for themselves and their children. I described Minister Viner as conducting industrial relations as though firing a shotgun from the hip.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Minister for Social Security must also accept that description. On 25 November he mentioned six industrial disputes. Those six disputes and the details of wives and children being given sustenance have been used by Senator Chaney and parroted by other members of the Government, particularly Senator Walters, in their criticism of spouses receiving social welfare payments. Senator Chaney mentioned the giant Utah company. Of course, that company is a subsidiary of the General Electric company. Senator Chaney referred to the 600 people involved in an industrial dispute with Utah. Of course, the provocative matter in that industrial dispute was the use of apprentices. As anybody with any industrial understanding would know, that was a provocation that obviously extended the dispute. Senator Chaney referred to the 471 wives and their children who received $445,000 in sustenance. The use by large companies such as Utah of apprentices as a reserve of strike breakers to sour industrial relations and of course to extend industrial disputes is a cynical use of the gigantic power companies such as that have in isolated areas in this country.

It is very significant that most of the examples used by Senator Chaney involve giant companies with tremendous economic power. That is what we are talking about. Unfortunately, Senator Martin could not understand Labor senators drawing attention to the fact that in the very year this dispute took place the Utah company made a profit of $160m. We must contrast the $445,000 paid to the spouses of the strikers involved with that profit of $160m. Of course, in previous years Utah has shipped hundreds of millions of dollars out of this country. I suggest that that profit is a result of the sweat of Australian miners. I have already said that Senator Chaney made a very significant interjection during the speech of my colleague, Senator Colston, when he asked: 'What is all the fuss about?' That was when Senator Colston was referring to the smallness of the amount of money that was involved-$5m. The $5m represents 0.5 per cent of total welfare and social security outlays of this Government. That is the size of the issue we are involved in. But it means a great deal for the women and children who in every case are battling against a giant company.

I refer to that matter because we are talking in reference to this legislation only about the longest and most bitter industrial disputes, disputes that have continued for more than seven days. The Government is proposing to take the work test entitlement away from women, which at the moment they are entitled to. The Government wants to deny women the dignity of being entitled to their own social welfare payments. Indeed, the Government is treating them as chattels of their husbands. That is something that Australian women in this day and age will not tolerate.

Senator Chaney named only one company in his speech of 25 November. That is significant because I think Senator Chaney was a bit ashamed to see the list of companies and some of the industrial relations records of the six companies involved. The Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd was involved. Senator Chaney certainly mentioned the number of wives concerned who received assistance but he did not mention the industrial record of BHP. It is well known that BHP often engineered disputes at its Whyalla shipyard if it looked like being late with the delivery of a ship. The company then blamed the unions for the delay, thus avoiding late delivery costs that would otherwise have run into hundreds of thousands of dollars. BHP has been provocative and reactionary as an employer; after 10 years of resistance it finally conceded that its workers were entitled to a tea break provided they did not sit down or talk to each other during the break. This is the company that only last week talked about closing down plant and putting off at least 3,000 Australian workers in the steel industry.

Another company was involved the name of which I do not think Senator Chaney was game to mention. He referred to wives receiving sustenance from social security payments but he did not mention the dispute or the name of the Gove alumina company. Although 550 employees were on strike, only six wives were being paid unemployment benefit. Of course, Gove alumina is the company that is suspected by the Icelandic Government of transfer pricing its products to avoid tax. The Icelandic Government is looking at the inflated price it is paying for materials produced in Australia. That is not surprising when it is recalled that one of the companies involved in that operation is Alcoa of Australia Ltd. which , of course, is before the High Court on a similiar matter. This attitude is typical of Senator Chaney and Government members. It entails mindless opposition to the trade union movement and the complete support of big business.

I refer now to the 10-week Blackwater dispute over a housing subsidy to miners. Senator Chaney was very upset because 4,500 people were on strike and 411 wives were granted unemployment relief. It is well to remember the statistic that in the year 1980, 39.7 per cent of disputes were caused by management. Senator Harradine used another figure of 21 per cent relating to disputes over issues of safety and working conditions. Thus we can see who causes the vast majority of disputes in this country. The dispute at Blackwater was a particular type of dispute because it was caused, sustained and nutured by, in this case, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Howard). I remind Senator Chaney of the inglorious end to that dispute. Senator Martin, one of the other speakers on the Government side in this debate, berated the people involved in this dispute. She said that an almost carnival atmosphere surrounding women registering for unemployment was portrayed through the media. I will refer to some of the Press clippings of that time in Queensland. There is no better source than the Courier -Mail, which on 3 September 1980 stated:
The key to the possible resolution of the central Queensland miners' strike is a 1973 letter which the State Treasurer, Dr Edwards, admitted he came across ' through luck.'
He was told about it during a visit to Blackwater, but exhaustive inquires revealed nothing until last week.
The letter was written in 1973 by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Hogan. I think a significant paragraph in this article tells us exactly who causes industrial disputes. It states:
The Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, was involved and had a heated telephone discussion with Dr Edwards, but he eventually accepted the letter.

That is another example of how this Government even outdoes the efforts of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) regarding Telecom Australia in provoking industrial disputes. If this Bill is carried women and children are going to suffer because of the incompetence of these people. Senator Martin not only abused, in words that I have described, the wives of strikers but also she said that the public saw and understood what the issues were. I again remind the Senate and Senator Martin of what the Bulletin said on 9 September. It stated:

Striking Queensland miners are far ahead of the Federal Government in terms of public support, according to the Morgan Gallup Poll. And support for the strikers is at its strongest in their home State.
Eighty per cent of people had heard of it, and of this figure 38 per cent thought the miners were right, compared with 22 per cent for the government . . .
In Queensland,-
Senator Martin's State-
56 percent thought the miners were right, compared with 17 percent for the government.
To show a cross-sectional view of the polls recorded at the time I quote from the Australian of 5 September under the heading 'Coal strikers find they have lots of friends'. The article states:
Almost 60 per cent of Australians support the striking central Queensland coal miners, while a quarter believe trade unions are uncontrollable, according to surveys commissioned by the Australian.

The miners' dispute survey shows that almost half-46.4 per cent-of those disagreeing with the Government's intentions to make the miners pay tax on subsidised housing are otherwise Liberal-NCP supporters.

That is the answer to Senator Martin and that is the answer to the situation that will exist if this Government has the temerity to go to the people of Australia. The Australian people will reject it.
Senator Walsh-Petersen was supporting that strike.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh reminds me that Premier Bjelke-Petersen supported that strike. I wonder whether the problems of Queensland's Liberal Party exist because people such as Senator Martin are so out of touch with people in the provincial and outback areas of this country. For a moment I will look at the broad perspective of the cost to the community of strikes and other significant areas of cost. The cost of strikes is relatively insignificant when compared with lost production due to absenteeism, industrial accidents, injuries and unemployment.

INTERJECT.PARA: Recently the Government estimated that each year there were at least 300 fatalities and 300,000 disabling injuries. These resulted in the loss of one million working weeks. If one million working weeks were lost in 1980-the year that I am using-as a result of fatalities and injuries the value of production lost amounted to $448m. In 1980 the number of officially unemployed people averaged at 401,850. If all these people had been employed the gross domestic product would have increased by $7,912m. Absenteeism is more difficult to estimate accurately but one estimate is that on any one day about 4 per cent of the work-force is taking sickies. If this figure were applied to 1980 the direct cost to the economy of absenteeism would have been $4,917m. I mention figures relating to strikes, unemployment, absenteeism, injuries and fatalities in 1980 because if we look at them and work out the percentages we find that industrial disputes represent only 2.1 per cent of the estimated value of loss of production; injuries and fatalities represent 3.3 per cent, unemployment 58.2 per cent and absenteeism 36.2 per cent.
Senator Messner-Would you prescribe something?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner interjected 'would you prescribe something?' The Labor Party would do something to alleviate these problems. We would encourage safety. We would prevent health hazards and we would do something about unemployment-something that this Government has not been able to do. We would certainly make sure that the $13.5 billion lost in the four categories that I have mentioned was arrested. We would not seek to knock over $5m which is all this Bill could reasonably be thought to save Government coffers.

INTERJECT.PARA: If we break down the figures relating to industrial disputes we find that 65 per cent of all industrial disputes lasted two days or less. Only 21 per cent of workers were involved in disputes which lasted longer than two days and only 8.9 per cent of all strikers were involved in strikes of 10 days or more. In this context I do not support the Australian Democrats' amendment because I estimate that it probably applies to only 5 per cent of the industrial disputes that occur. Senator Chaney said that the Bill is not an anti-strike Bill but one aimed at restricting the community's subsidisation of strikes. If honourable senators look at the figures they can see that the amount of money involved is pitiful. The Government has done nothing to tackle big areas of cost to the community. It has an abysmal record in solving major problems where people are being wasted, particularly the major area-unemployment.

Although this legislation applies to both sexes it is an insult to Australian women that they are not entitled to the welfare benefit. It would be absolutely insulting to offer them the special benefit that the Government is offering them . The six examples of disputes that were mentioned by Senator Chaney show the Government's fetish for big business and its blind acceptance of whatever big business does. So far as the Government is concerned it does not matter who causes industrial disputes. No matter how much a dispute may have been provoked the Government will back any employer, under any circumstance. Conversely every trade unionist is wrong and every spouse is to be victimised.

I did mention the other possibility of why we have this legislation before us. If the two pieces of legislation are taken together, as I said earlier, some people will say that it is a mad attempt to save the Victorian Government. It may be an attempt to prevent the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) from making his expected bid for leadership. I do not know what the Prime Minister has in his mind. Of course, one could not really anticipate what he would ever have in his mind. I want to be evenhanded in my criticism but he has certainly said that the Victorian Premier stands on his own. The Prime Minister has prepared the way for dumping Mr Thompson. Like a snake shedding his skin, he has covered his tracks on that matter. If the Government wishes to fight this issue and have a double dissolution on it we will be very happy to take it through the length and breadth of this country. We have people all over Australia who-as the polls that were taken during that Queensland dispute indicate-are not as foolish as this Government thinks they are. They are intelligent and capable of working out who are the people ripping off the country or who are the people causing the problems that this community faces. We will be very happy to fight that issue. We would like that to be a trigger mechanism and we would like the election that would flow from it.
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3 ) 1981 [No. 2] (1982) which we are debating in the guise of a Social Services Bill really amounts to what we might call a lack of industrial relations Bill. The purpose of the legislation brought forward by the Government is, in the minds of the Australian Democrats, to use the social services legislation to create mischief, dispute and dissention within the community to no good end. At this stage I have pleasure in seconding the amendment moved last week by my colleague Senator Janine Haines to the motion for the second reading of the Bill . The purpose of the amendment is to create a situation which the Australian Democrats believe is a reasonable compromise in this matter which repeatedly has been brought before the Senate. As things stand in the legislation at present the wives of strikers are able to get dole payments after one week. Our amendment would make that period two weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted that in the figures quoted by Senator Childs, only 8.9 per cent of strikes extend beyond 10 days. Senator Childs said that he doubted whether 5 per cent of people would be eligible for this payment if the two-week period were to lapse. That is more or less what the Australian Democrats have in mind. If we had a situation such as this there would be a number of effects. It would mean a considerable reduction in the cost to the taxpayer of providing this benefit. In these days, when admittedly this sum of money is not great and everything which is in millions of dollars is of importance, I think it will continue to be increasingly difficult for the Government to get revenue. Revenue can be derived only from taxation and has to be spread over a variety of requirements which have priorities. I think there are some things which should have priority over whether or not the wife of a striker should have this money after one week or two weeks. That is not to say-as Senator Haines has said before on behalf of the Democrats and as I will say again-that we believe that this benefit should be withdrawn completely. We are opposed to that for reasons which I will come to shortly.

If this amendment were carried it would mean a considerable reduction in the cost to the taxpayer providing this benefit when the average duration of strikes is taken into account. It would also meet the objections which I and other Democrat senators have heard from many members of the community. If the benefit is given after only one week it might encourage strikes which might not otherwise have happened-frivolous strikes. That may or may not be the case. I will not debate that here. But it is certainly true that many members of the community think that that is the case. It is important that they understand or think they understand that their tax money is being spent in a way reasonable to themselves.

However, the amendment would still meet the human rights and purely humane requirements, which we think are so essential, that financial assistance should be available to the wives and families of strikers after not too long a period. In other words, although I am aware-the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), I think, has made this clear and perhaps will do so again-that there are failsafe measures whereby people who are virtually destitute or are close to being destitute can apply for a special benefit. We do not believe that that is adequate, we do not believe that people who may not wish to contribute to the strike or who may not approve of it at all should be forced into that kind of situation. We believe it is reasonable that the community should protect these people who, after all, are not strikers and are not involved in industrial situations, but are merely married to a striker and, in many cases, have children who are dependent on some form of income. We think it is inhuman and inhumane that it should be suggested that this be removed from them.

I raised the idea of this amendment in November when this legislation was previously before us. It was my fault then that I did not raise it sufficiently early for its merits as a compromise to become obvious before the vote on the second reading stages was taken. That is not the case now. The Australian Democrats formally moved the amendment last week. Debate on the Bill was then adjourned. I think there has been time for what the Australian Democrats believe to be a reasonable and sane compromise in this matter to be considered.

Unhappily, we are in an unfortunate phase for any kind of middle ground to be considered. I know that the Senate, the other place and the public generally have been regaled with a non-stop campaign of politicking that might well lead us to believe that there will be a State election in Victoria next week. Almost everything that has been said here has been coloured by that, as always happens when there is an election. But if honourable senators can divert their attention from that immediate vote-catching objective for a little while, I ask for some serious and thoughtful consideration of the Australian Democrats amendment-the Haines amendment. My words are addressed in particular to the Government.

The Government-I stress this-has only two clear alternatives. Its first alternative is to accept the fact that its Bill will fail and that the benefit will go on being paid to strikers' wives, as at present, after one week. Its second alternative is to accept the Australian Democrats amendment, which would allow the payment to be made after two weeks. The Government should have been trying to work its way towards achieving the best possible position that it can achieve. I reiterate that the only way in which this can be achieved is by voting for our amendment, which is a perfectly respectable proposition which I think anybody in this chamber would concede is a compromise. I might add that-I will deal with this matter later-it is not a compromise that came off the top of my head but one that has come to me from a wide cross-section of the public whom we have consulted. That point was raised more often by the people whom we consulted than anything else that I can consider in the light of this legislation.

I think the Government has a responsibility to work towards the best possible position it can achieve. It will be a matter of great interest to the public to see what happens-whether the Government accepts what we see and it must see as the better situation, or whether it will throw this away wilfully, by voting against our proposal. If it chooses to vote against our proposal I would regard that as a most serious matter. In the minds of all Australian Democrats and, I think, in the minds of the public it would reiterate that none of the lessons of the last few years have been learnt; that the method being used here is confrontation politics at all costs; and that there is no wish or will or effort by the Government to use this place and its debating processes in any way to try to arrive at a compromise situation which might be a better one for the public and for the community. No; that is not to happen. Both sides-the Australian Labor Party and the Government-have told us that they are not willing to accept our amendment. This is being done, of course, for precisely opposite reasons. Where is the rationality? Where is the sense in that? Is it not possible, as the years pass in this place, for there to be, at least in a matter like this, a reasonable attempt to get some sort of compromise that would allow this business to go ahead without it becoming the chronically divisive issue-the gage thrown down-that it has become?

I am sick and tired of industrial issues being turned into political matters by both sides. People have suffered in this country again and again because every strike and every piece of industrial legislation becomes a political matter. More intelligent and sane societies do not do that any more. They do not put their people to the cost of that sort of political point scoring on either or both sides. I wish that that would happen here. I see this matter of the fate of our amendment, not just because it is our amendment but because of its nature, as a useful test of good intentions and as an indication of whether the Government and indeed the Opposition-the Labor Party-really have the interest of the community at heart or whether the Government has simply raised this matter through a spirit of mischief in order to provide itself with what its own members have been calling for some time a trigger for a double dissolution. Again we have the political motivation. There was no attempt to see this issue in human terms. There was no attempt to see this issue in terms of the benefit to the people of Australia. It was seen in terms of a political issue and, in this case, a double dissolution issue. On that point what I have to say is highly relevant to this debate because the Government has indeed made it quite plain that this Bill is back before us again because it wants the trigger for a possible double dissolution. (Quorum formed). Before that quorum was formed I was making the point that I see this matter as a test of good intentions and an indication of whether the Government and the Opposition-the Labor Party-really have the interests of the community at heart or whether indeed this has been raised purely through a spirit of mischief. If indeed the Government accepts our amendment I will happily eat my words; I will be delighted to find that a spirit of compromise is abroad in this place. I look forward to the Minister's statements on that matter a little later in this debate.

The question of the double dissolution, as I was saying, is highly relevant to this debate because the Government has brought forward this Bill repeatedly saying that that is its real intention and that if we do not pass it this will be the trigger for a double dissolution. Let me make the Australian Democrat's position abundantly clear. We would like to see the Government run its full term . We have no wish to see a general election this year or at any time before the end of next year when one is properly due. If there is a double dissolution election this year it will not be because the Australian Democrats want it but because the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wants it. Why would he want it? A number of reasons have been advanced. One is that he feels he might do better electorally with an election this year than next year or that he might do better with a double dissolution election than a half senate election. I should have thought that an examination of the latest gallup poll figures issued today would give the Government serious cause for concern in that regard. Another reason might be the Prime Minister's feeling that the economy will be worse next year than this year and that it will be a good idea to have an election this year. All these theories have been canvassed, and all these statements are repeatedly made in the Press and other media. They are relevant to the discussion of this Bill and the way in which it has been so widely touted by the Government as a double dissolution trigger.

My point is that we, the Australian Democrats, criticise the Government and indeed the Labor Party for loose political talk of an election this year which, frankly, is something the Australian people want and need about as much as they want and need a hole in the head. What we need now is stability in government, and the Government getting on with the job sensibly in a style that will allow the maintenance of community and business confidence, not the destruction of that confidence so that people never know whether an election will be held this year, next year or at any time. That is certainly what we intend to try to maintain in the society in every way that is humanely possible. Senator Haines made the point last week that if the Government will not accept our amendment we will vote against the Government amendment Bill which is designed to abolish this benefit completely. We dislike having to contribute towards one or other of the extremes represented here by the Government and the Labor Party, but unfortunately that is something we have to live with. In the not too distant future when there is an Australian Democrat Government in this country, that will no longer be the case. I look forward with my colleagues to that time.

We will vote against the Bill first because we believe it is wrong, and that this is basically a matter of human rights, and especially women's rights. A married woman's right not to be penalised explicity for what her husband does seems to me to be a right which is or should be beyond doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or has done to him.

—Or has done to him, as Senator Chipp said. I do not think there is any doubt about that at all. This is an issue of fundamental importance. It is not right or proper that a woman should be penalised for something simply because she is married to a man who is doing something.
—Or is not doing something.

—Or is not doing something, in this case, as Senator Haines pointed out; that is, not working. I cannot believe that we will have conspiracies in Australia in which families-women, children and all-are all tarred with the same brush and say: 'It is great, Dad. We have a strike and we have to fight for our rights. I do not want to go to school, have shoes or anything like that. We really have to push this'. That is rubbish. There is no reason whatsoever to suppose that any type of thing like that is happening in Australia. That is our first consideration, and we are all agreed on it. What the Government is proposing to do is wrong; it is discriminatory, unfair and it is againt human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Our next reason is that considerable research in the community on the part of the Australian Democrats has lead us to believe that the bulk of the community would find the withdrawal of this benefit repugnant because it would be seen as an unfair strike-breaking weapon. I should think, for very much the same reasons as I have outlined that people do not believe it is fair enough to take a social services amendment of this sort and use it basically for strike breaking. I have not yet heard, but I hope to hear, reasons from the Minister as to why this interpretation cannot reasonably be applied to this Bill. I cannot see any other reason for it. If there are other reasons I would very much like to hear the Minister elucidate them in due course. Senator Haines very reasonably raised last week the Government's erroneous perception that wives somehow have the universal ability to influence their husbands' decisions as to whether they will accept a call to strike. Of course she was right when she said that they do not have any such influence. I shall quote Senator Haines's comments in the Hansard of 17 March when she said something I could not put better or indeed as well. Senator Haines, speaking last week about this legislation, stated:

There can be no question that the motivation behind this legislation had nothing to do with ending or limiting industrial disputes. There seem to be no reasons behind the Government's reintroduction of this legislation other than to try to intimidate some unionists, to cause family disharmony, to punish innocent women and children or-this I believe to be the most likely reason-to take advantage of the average person's ignorance about industrial or legislative matters in order to induce hysteria in the community and then, what is worse, to prey upon this for political advantage. It appears to us to be nothing more nor less than a cynical exercise in scare tactics.

I say 'Amen' to that. I would like to feel that in the intervening week the Government has taken these words to heart and has thought again. I urge it to do so even at this late stage. It would be a remarkable thing that we would all applaud if that happened. The Government has a clear opportunity to give the lie to all those things that have been said about confrontative politics in Australia and to show that it is able to govern this country while taking into account the reasonable views put forward by a dissenting group. The Australian Democrat senators put this forward as a new idea. After all, we represent the views of close on one million Australian voters. It is a view we have a responsibility to put forward. I suggest that the Government has a responsibility to listen to it and consider it carefully. Is it good enough that the Government should, on its minority of the total vote-it is a fact that it governs on a minority vote-want its way at all times and on all things? If it does not get its way, should it get a fit of the huffs and take its bat and ball , not home, but off to the Governor-General to ask for a double dissolution? I suggest to the Government yet again, so it is quite clear on this point, that it can come much nearer what it actually wants by supporting the Australian Democrats amendment than by any other means. I would like an assurance from the Minister. If what I say is not correct I would like him to explain why.

The amendment would alter the present situation, in which the wives of strikers are paid the dole after one week, so that they got that payment only after two weeks. The community and industrial relations generally, we believe, would be the healthier for that.

I will spend two or three minutes discussing the divisiveness in the community over industrial relations issues. It is a matter of deep concern to the Australian Democrats. It was one of the things which led to the formation of the party. We feel that it is one of the great issues that has never really been tackled. The Government's tendency to exploit this divisiveness in the community is a very mischievous and evil thing to do. It is, in fact, playing with fire. Industrial relations in this country is a complete shambles. We need something done about basic issues such as fewer unions, more rationally based. This is something the Government is starting to look at. We hope it will come forward with more rational comments than we have heard so far. If there is to be a reasonable government initiative on this matter let us see it. Let it be agreed to, preferably by industry, employers and the unions themselves. I suggest there is no harm in consulting these people rather than someone in the Government coming forward with something off the top of his head.

There needs to be much less political interference and play in the process of conciliation. There are examples of this in other countries. Canada has a system of industrial task forces. There is an attempt first to take any kind of dispute right away from publicity and from the political and legal fields. A group of arbitrators, chosen from industry, come together. They are selected by all parties to the dispute from a large panel of available people who know their subject. Those people go away and discuss the dispute away from politics, legalities and publicity. I gather that a very large number of disputes are settled at that stage. It is understandable that they should be settled at that stage because they are not made political footballs and brought into the area of provocation which is often so tragic and disastrous for people in this country. I would have thought that we would have learned that lesson by now. Are we doomed to go on learning it over and over again, year after year, causing more and more trouble and strife for our own people?

We need a sensible system of industrial democracy in this country along the lines of the Bill proposed by my colleague, Senator John Siddons, which recently passed the Senate. It was of great distress to me to see the relative unawareness of the media in this country to that Bill. After all, it was one of the most intelligent and basic initiatives in this area which has been taken in this country in many a long year. Because it did not represent trouble, discord or strife it appears to have been virtually ignored so I mention it again now. The Bill provided for an industrial democracy mechanism. An economic reward of an 8 per cent reduction in company tax would be given to those organisations prepared to meet the requirements of the industrial democracy organisation set up under the Bill. That would mean a proper profit sharing basis, work groups and worker representation on their boards. It is an industrial formula which is not new. It has had remarkable success in other countries and in the companies controlled by Senator Siddons himself. The lessons are there. Why cannot some notice be taken of them? The reason is that there is no interest in good government by honourable senators on the other side of the House. The Government is interested in confrontation and obstruction. It does not desire to see the old hatreds between the worker and the boss disappear. Apparently it suits the Government to exploit those hatreds, see that they are there forever and use them for its own base ends. The legislation we are considering now is another example of that.

The most recent mess the Government has created is the chaotic lack of a reasonable wage fixing policy in this country. The Government has literally let the whole wage fixing system run loose. If it pretends to be any sort of government at all it should not be meddling with piddling legislation like this in order to cause trouble. It should come to grips with the problem of how to get a decent wage fixing system and understand that until we get it we will have trouble month after month and year after year. The situation will get worse. The blame can be laid directly at the door of the Government because of its miserable failure to cope with the problem. I suggest to the Government that it work towards solutions such as these to the problems. Even if it made a small effort I think it would regain some of the respect from the community which it has so dismally lost in recent months.

I am convinced that the Government consists largely of good men who want to do things but who now appear to be without direction. I cannot believe that all the people sitting opposite me in this chamber and those in the other place do not worry about the things I have mentioned. All we ask is that they do something about them and induce the Government to do something about them. We should have an end to things like this ridiculous little Bill which is brought back to us. Any attempt at compromise or conciliation is not listened to. I would like to hear what the Minister has to say about that even now. I feel we might get somewhere. There are solutions to the problems I have mentioned. There should be consultation within the community and co-operation in a reasonable decent way, not the sort of miserable, piddling confrontation that we see in this Bill. I commend the amendment to the Senate.
