TALK.START.PARA: —In the closing minutes of the debate on the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982) the Bill has been described as-I think the expression was used by Mr Mason-a piddling Bill. It is true that the Bill is one which is not particularly large in size but I think some people would regard the principle which it contains as being of some importance. The principle which it raises is whether the Australian taxpayer, through the Commonwealth Government, should automatically extend income support to the families of strikers during a strike. That is a matter on which I am prepared to say there is room for some honest differences of opinion. But I think most Australians would say that it is a question of some seriousness and one which certainly warrants the attention of the national Parliament, and not the sort of disparaging wipe-off that it was given in the closing minutes of the debate. The second reading speech on the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill proposes that, for so long as a person's spouse is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit because of involvement in industrial action; or unwilliness to undertake suitable work; or failure to take reasonable steps to obtain such work, that person will also be ineligble for unemployment benefit. Additionally, a person will be ineligble for unemployment benefit for so long as payment of that benefit to the person's spouse is postponed because of their misconduct as a worker; because they have become voluntarily unemployed; or because they have failed to accept an offer of suitable employment.

That measure is proposed in the context of an income maintenance system in Australia which is extremely broad. The Australian taxpayer supports, through the Commonwealth Government and through the Department of Social Security, approximately two million Australians with regular payments. That figure of two million is made up principally of age pensioners of whom there are about 1.4 million. It is made up of in excess of 200,000 invalid pensioners. It is made up of over 300,000 people on unemployment benefit. It comprises the major part of the Commonwealth' expenditure on social security and welfare. It comprises a bill which is met by the Australian taxpayer to the tune of approximately $40 a week per taxpayer. This is a significant matter. It is a matter of great interest to all Australians because all of them may at some stage be dependent upon that system of income support and all of those who work, earn and pay taxes contribute to it.

The question which is raised in this debate and which falls to be determined in a vote of the Senate is whether automatic assistance is to be provided to the families of strikers and to others who for various reasons are not entitled to unemployment benefit. That, as I said before, is an important question. It has been debated in part during the debate on the basis that to refuse unemployment benefit in these circumstances is to bring hardship on to innocent people. I, of course, can understand that that is a matter which would be of concern to all honourable senators in this place and, indeed, to all Australians. I can do no more than remind the Senate that the provision does not deny income support to people who are without money of their own.

As was indicated in the Bill, as was expanded upon in the speeches in this place the last time the matter was before the Senate and as was outlined by Senator Scott when he spoke in the debate on this occasion, the proposal that special benefit should be available in cases of extreme hardship has been defined to ensure that those people who are without cash resources will be entitled to receive special benefit at the same rate as unemployment benefit would be payable at present. One is looking at a situation in which the Government is not saying that the families of strikers or people who are out of employment for one of the reasons that I have already outlined should not receive support, rather the Government is saying that the first call for support should be on that family's own resources. As I indicated some months ago, the position would be that where there were adequate cash resources to meet current commitments and where there were additional cash resources equal to the amount of unemployment benefit which would be payable, special benefit would not be payable. In other circumstances special benefit would, indeed, be payable. I refer those honourable senators who want a more detailed description of the operation of that to Senator Scott's recent speech, to my original laying down of the conditions which I had outlined to the Australian Democrats before this matter came into Parliament last time, to page 2539 and page 2540 of the Senate Hansard of 25 November.

A good deal of the debate in this place has been conducted on the basis that there are no real difficulties about strikes in Australia, that there are strikes for good reason and that really we should all be much more understanding about strikes. I think that a very significant part of the Australian population believes that it is time that we were considerably less understanding about strikes and more keen to see an end to the strike activity in this country. More recently, in debate in the Senate, I have had occasion to refer to things which have been said by the Premier of New South Wales about some of the trade union activity in New South Wales of recent time which he has described in terms which I have no doubt honourable senators opposite would call union bashing. I refer to those statements. I do not want to go into them at length again unless honourable senators opposite would like me to repeat Mr Wran's words.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should think you would not. It upsets me!
—Since it upsets the Opposition Whip let me repeat what was said by Mr Wran. A report of his words reads:

SPEECH.PARA: ''Some sections of the power workers have declared war on their workmates in N. S.W.'', he told the House.
''It would seem they have declared war on the community itself''.
''The community should not bow to this blackmail, and I want to assure the community that the Government will not bow to blackmail''.

That is what Mr Wran has recently had to say about some of the trade union activity in his State. Something else which has been said recently is that Mr Wran has said of the psychiatric nurses that they have desecrated their profession. We are looking at a position where there is, in fact, often trade union activity which is of a totally anti-social kind. I would have thought that debate in this place ought be conducted also with a recognition that that is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody is arguing that.

—I am pleased that the Leader of the Australian Democrats now says that nobody is arguing about that. It is admitted, apparently, from different parts of the chamber that much of the strike activity might be described as quite anti-social in character. If the Bill before the chamber is not passed it will remain true that no matter how anti-social the behaviour of the trade unions there will be an automatic entitlement to support under the social security system for many of the families of strikers engaged in that behaviour. A balance has to be established. This Government believes that the proper balance is to be established by not ensuring automatic entitlement to social security benefits in these circumstances but by providing access to social security benefits only in circumstances where the family does not have assets or money of its own. I believe that any family which has its own cash resources ought to be thrown on to those cash resources before being thrown on to the resources of the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: There are quite clear choices in this matter before the chamber. There has been an attempt, in my view, to confuse and muddy the issue by the moving of an amendment by the Democrats, who have suggested that they would prefer to see the law changed so that assistance is denied for two weeks of a strike. That is the rather extraordinary proposition: The Government would refuse a subsidy for short strikes but would grant a subsidy for long strikes. If we look at the information on strikes which was put before the Senate when this matter was last debated it becomes pretty clear that the sort of situation which is surely most objectionable to the taxpayer is when there are long, extended strikes which are very costly to the country, extremely inconvenient to the community and which still give rise to an automatic entitlement to social security benefits. I defy anybody to describe to me the logic of saying that we will refuse to give a subsidy for a two-week strike but will give a subsidy for a three-week strike. That seems to me to be quite absurd. The Government has no difficulty in saying that it will not accept the amendment which has been put forward by the Democrats.

To turn the matter into one of women's rights shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the operation of the social security system. It is true that throughout the whole of the operation of that system income testing has been applied not to individuals but to families. Whether one looks at a male employee or a female employee, their entitlement to various benefits, including the unemployment benefit, is restricted by an income test which applies not merely to the income of the person seeking the benefit but also to the income which is being received by the spouse of the person seeking the benefit. So as a matter of principle the whole of the social security system is based not on women's rights or men's rights but on trying to ensure that families receive basic support in circumstances where they need it.

We are dealing here with a situation where, by wilful act or an act which is not the responsibility of the Government, an individual has deprived himself of the ability to earn his living for a period. In that circumstance it seems absolutely artificial to have the spouse of that person exempted from the equivalent to the income test and being regarded as a person who can seek the assistance of the social security system. I believe there are no grounds in logic for support being extended in those circumstances. I believe the legislation should be welcomed by this place. The fact of the matter is that we are seeking to go from a situation at present where there is an automatic entitlement to benefit in certain circumstances to a situation where there will be an entitlement to benefit only where the family does not have cash resources of its own. I believe that is a fair situation to arrive at. It is a situation which this Government ought to maintain.

One of the matters raised throughout the debate concerns the question of whether the Government is using the social security system as an industrial weapon. It seems to me to be quite clear that what is being sought, in fact, by those who would oppose this change is the use of the social security system to ensure that the strike weapon can be more effectively wielded. That is a principle which was deserted by this country many years ago. It was deserted by politicians from the other side of politics to me. In the last debate I referred to the description of the history of this matter which is contained in Mr Kewley 's Australian Social Security Today. I referred to pages 132 and 133 of that book. The book quotes from a letter to the Director of Social Services dated May 1948 in which Senator McKenna, the Minister for Social Services in the Chifley Government, said:
All unions represented at the Conference with me in Sydney on 23rd April accepted the principle that the Commonwealth could not permit unemployment benefit to be used for financing strikes.
That was accepted as long ago as 1948 by the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, but it was not for wives. Be fair dinkum.
—Again, the interjectors--
—Read on.

—I will be reading on. The interjectors cheerfully ignore the fact that assistance will be available to those who do not have money of their own, but there will not be assistance to those who have it. A statement was put down by Mr Chifley in 1948. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In connection with the payment of unemployment benefit to persons involved in or affected by the present Queensland industrial dispute, the Social Services Consolidation Act provides that benefit is not payable to an applicant whose unemployment is due to him being a direct participant in a strike.
These words are significant.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were more jobs available under Labor than there are under Fraser.

—I ask the noisy members of the Opposition to listen with their ears instead of with their mouths. I am quoting from a statement made by Mr Chifley, a Labor Prime Minister. Honourable senators opposite may find it enjoyable. Mr Chifley went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to other persons involved in or affected by an industrial dispute, the Minister for Social Services has issued instructions which are being observed by the Department of Social Services in Queensland at present and throughout the Commonwealth. These instructions are the outcome of a full consideration of the relevant parts of the Act of a Cabinet sub-committee early in 1947.

In brief, the instructions embody the following principles: In respect of unions on strike and unions sponsoring a strike of its members in key positions, members of these unions . . . whether directly participating in the strike, or unemployed as a direct or indirect consequence of the strike, are not to be regarded as eligible to receive unemployment benefit.
In respect of unions not on strike, or apparently having no members on strike, members of these unions are to be regarded as eligible to receive unemployment benefit.

The fact of the matter is that a nice new technique has emerged in Australia. The technique is that if one goes out on strike and stays out on strike in one of these towns for a long time, one's wife goes down and tries to collect the unemployment benefit. I believe that that automatic entitlement to use the social security system in a strike situation is something which is not acceptable to the Australian people and it is not something which is acceptable to this Government. I commend the legislation to the Senate. As I indicated before, the Government will oppose the amendment which was moved by the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Did the Minister deliberately ignore the valid questions which Senator Harradine raised in good faith about safety measures and the other occasions when people can be stood down, or did he genuinely forget? Usually he treats the chamber with the utmost courtesy. The Australian Democrats would have been interested to hear his replies to those questions.

—In my submission there is no point of order. In any event, this is the second time this Bill has been debated. Throughout my speech I was given scant courtesy by members of the Opposition and I feel I have given quite enough indication of the Government's position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I firmly support the principles and philosophy of the present Family Law Act. I made that clear when I began this speech what seems an interminable time ago on 16 March, and I state it again tonight. I accept and support the philosophy of the Family Law Act to the extent that it removes the concept of matrimonial fault, thereby ending the humiliation, the bitterness and the hypocrisy which are associated with attempts to show who was the guilty party. I support the establishment of single-ground no-fault divorce as an advance which must on no account be jeopardised. I support, and I believe the Senate and this Parliament should support, the operation of a Family Court system whereby the Court, freed from the burden of attributing fault, can now concentrate on being satisfied as to the fact of marriage breakdown and on deciding thereafter the most equitable distribution of property, the proper level of maintenance and, above all, the best possible arrangements for the welfare of any children of the marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: I also expressed in my opening remarks my support for the general content of this legislation-the way in which it streamlines and will improve the operation of the family law system in various ways and the way in which it does that in the light of the accumulated experience in the operation of the family law system in the Family Court since 1975. The particular matter to which I was addressing myself and referring in the debate when it was adjourned a few weeks ago was the jurisdictional role of the Family Court and, in particular, the jurisdictional problems which can arise in relation to a number of areas of the Family Court's operation. The particular jurisdictional problem I mentioned, because it can be the most harrowing experience for the people involved. was in the custody jurisdiction of the Court when the claimants for custody involve more than the natural married parents of the child in question.

At the conclusion of my remarks on the last occasion I was drawing attention in particular to one case now before the High Court of Australia, the case of Fountain v. Alexander, which involved a custody battle over a 14-year-old boy being fought out simultaneously in three different courts-the High Court, the Family Court and the Supreme Court of New South Wales. That is manifestly an intolerable situation which ought not on any account to be repeated. I go on from here to say that unfortunately the present Bill does not mark in itself the achievement of a unified family law jurisdiction so as to make impossible in the future the repetition of experiences of this kind. There are in it amendments which endeavour to expand the jurisdiction of the Family Court within the limits of the Commonwealth's constitutional competence, but there is a doubt-there is no certainty-that these changes will in fact survive a High Court challenge. The case of Russell v. Russell and, more recently and to a lesser extent perhaps, the case of Gazzo do not give any cause for optimism at all about the High Court 's attitude to the reach of the Commonwealth's power in this area. Furthermore, it has been publicly reported that the Queensland Government, on the advice of that constitutional giant Sam Doumany, the State Attorney-General, will be mounting a High Court challenge to these amendments if they are passed. So, there is a very real question of their being at risk.

Furthermore, even if those amendments do survive such a High Court challenge, there are still a number of other matters not within the scope of the present Bill which I believe, and I hope other senators and members will believe, should be included in a unified family law jurisdiction but which are or which appear to be, in the present state of the law, beyond the reach of existing Commonwealth power. I am referring to matters which arise in the context of de facto marriages, particularly in respect of children and property. I am referring to questions which arise in relation to illegitimate children and also questions of adoption and wardship. Another set of questions which are obvious candidates for the jurisdiction of the family law and which may be within the reach of the Family Court under the Commonwealth's constitutional power as it stands at the moment concern problematical maintenance other than in the context of divorce proceedings. But these matters again are outside the range of attention of the present Bill.

Assuming that we in this Parliament can agree on the need for such unified jurisdiction for the Family Court, which I suppose is-no doubt we will hear later on from Senator Martyr how problematic it is-there are only two real options open, namely, references of powers by the States under the present provisions in section 51 (xxxvii) of the Constitution or, on the other hand, amendment of the Constitution. One might say that this is something of a Hobson' s choice kind of situation. On the one hand, we have the attitudes to constitutional reform generally which have been expressed in recent days by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in Sydney in his Edmund Barton lecture last Friday, when he put on record the view that any systematic or serious attempt at constitutional reform would be regarded by him, so long as he and his Government stayed in office, as divisive and out of the question.

There is a certain breath-taking quality about the effrontery demonstrated by someone like Malcolm Fraser who can claim that anyone's attempts to achieve constitutional reform are, in fact, divisive, given the track record of this man , a man who as I said a few days ago, is to the Australian Constitution what Attila the Hun was to the Roman empire. There are problems of course, in that political environment faced with that unreasoning hostility from unreasoning office bearers of this kind, in achieving sensible, systematic, rational constitutional amendment in areas which are even as crying out for it as the area of family law.

The alternative option is, of course, to secure a reference from the States under section 51 (xxxvii) of the Constitution but that is currently bogged down. That option is practically made unrealistic by a mixture of States' intransigence and a lack of political will on the part of the present Attorney- General. I suggested to the Attorney-General in this chamber on 21 November last that he should take his constitutional courage in both hands, stop running on the spot and accept referrals from those States which are, in fact, prepared to give them. If that means New South Wales alone, to begin with, so be it. Victoria will soon, undoubtedly, be following, particularly after the change of government on 3 April. I predict that South Australia and Tasmania will follow soon after. It is only by adventurous action of this kind and active performance on the part of our present governing leadership that we will get a rationalisation in this respect. The present Bill goes a reasonable distance along this particular path, but it does not go far enough.

Mr President, can I seek clarification at this stage as to just how much time I have got? The clock started at a quarter to the hour suggesting that I had only 15 minutes. But I think that is a mistake. I do, in fact, have another 20 minutes to go, not that I anticipate using that full amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had 15 minutes left for tonight, Senator.

—That is not as I understood it since I began on a non-broadcast day. I am distressed at that interpretation by the clerks. While the clerks are sorting that out, and consulting their rule books, perhaps I can proceed.
—Senator, as I understand it, the record shows that you spoke for 45 minutes previously.

—If the record shows that I spoke for 45 minutes, with the upmost respect, Mr President, the record is wrong. I spoke for no more than, in my recollection, 15 or 20 minutes on the previous occasion. I think the Hansard record will demonstrate that.
—I suggest that you carry on while we clarify the situation.

—I would appreciate clarification because there are a number of quite substantial things that I wish to say. I am somewhat alarmed by the approach of the clock to the hour. I am advised, with respect, Mr President, that I spoke for 15 minutes, based on a check of the Hansard, which is, in fact, my recollection. This suggests that there is no difficulty at all about my continuing on this occasion.
—We will clarify the situation.

—If you would, Mr President. I want to refer now to a number of aspects relating to the operation of the Family Court which are, of course, very much in issue as a result of the content of this Bill. I visited the Family Court in Melbourne for half a day three or four weeks ago with a specific object , which unfortunately is denied to most people by virtue of the closed nature of the Family Court proceedings at this stage. I was very much impressed by the evident efficiency, care and the compassion in the running of that court and the administration also of its counselling service. It seemed to me to be an environment very much conducive to the resolution of the difficult and very unhappy problems that often, in fact, confront it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is against that background that I wish to make some remarks on the following matters: The procedures relating to undefended divorces; the problems relating to court determinations affecting the welfare of children; the question of counselling; and the question of enforcement. In relation to undefended divorce applications, which is something which all honourable senators know has become a very controversial matter in the course of the consideration of this Bill, I found no indication whatsoever that the non-attendance of the parties or their legal representatives would make the slightest difference whatsoever to the way in which, in practice, undefended dissolutions are dealt with by the Family Court. At present, of course, it is only necessary for the applicant's legal representative to be present as distinct from the applicant being there in person. It is my impression and understanding that it is only in a minority of cases that both of the parties to the marriage, the applicant and the defendant are, in fact, there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, excuse me for interrupting you, but you did have a query about how much time you had. On further clarification the record shows that you do have the full 30 minutes. There was a misunderstanding of one figure .

—I am indebted to you, Mr President. I will try not to try the patience of the Senate or anyone else beyond endurance. But I am indebted to you , Mr President, for that clarification. In relation to such dissolutions, it is evident that the kind of technical defects that can often, of course, occur in the applications for such a dissolution can be easily remedied otherwise than by the presence of the parties. This can be done by a requisition through the post and by the appropriate affidavits being sworn or the appropriate material being supplied. If there are matters of substance about which the judge remains unsatisfied on the material before him, then, of course, it will remain, under this proposed legislation, perfectly open to him to require the attendance of the parties. Indeed, it will remain the case that if either of the parties to a divorce should not only want to be there personally but also require the attendance of the other party or his or her representative, then that can be done too.

SPEECH.PARA: The way in which the procedure, at present, operates is, to put it shortly, brisk, informal and extremely brief. I have seen undefended divorces being dealt with by Family Court judges in a period as short as 30 seconds. The judge will simply say: 'I grant a decree nisi in the usual terms'. The papers will be shuffled across his desk and that will be it. The average length of the judicial determination of the formal decree nisi proceedings, in the period that I observed the Family Court, was perhaps between one minute and three minutes. Certainly, on no occasion did it take more than five minutes and then only because there was some uncertainty as to whether the affidavit in question had been served on the other party. There is no evidence whatsoever, both in my direct experience or in the experience reported to me by others who practise and work in this jurisdiction, to suggest that those who appear at these hearings either want a degree of ceremony in their divorce or, to the extent that they do appear at the moment, notice in any way the conspicuous lack of ceremony which operates at the moment. Obviously, there are many more things that can be said about the divorce by post controversy. I will save them up to the Committee stage. At this stage I simply want to put on record my strong belief that most of the argument that we are getting on this subject has no regard to the reality as it operates at the moment and is based on a wholly romantic perception of the formality and the solemnity of the dissolution proceedings as they are conducted at the moment.

In so far as the welfare of children is concerned, which is another crucial aspect of the way the Court presently operates and a topic which is addressed to a limited extent by the present Bill, it has to be noted that this is overwhelmingly, perhaps, the most important aspect of the Family Court's procedure in terms of the impact that decisions can have on the lives of people. I believe that there is a need for the greater use in this part of the Court's jurisdiction for separate representation for children so as to ensure that their interests are maintained and promoted as a separate and distinct point of reference for the Court. I believe also very much in the need for early intervention by counselling, through the Court's agencies, to avoid protracted and unsatisfactory custody battles. The statistics that have emerged from the Family Court jurisdiction show clearly that cases where courts have to make custody and access orders where agreement cannot be reached between the parties through the assistance of counselling or otherwise are those cases which undoubtedly cause the most trouble subsequently.

In this respect I welcome also the present amendment to clause 21, as it has been further proposed to be amended by the Attorney's latest offering, which will abolish the arbitrary rule presently applying prohibiting the court from making an order against the wishes of a child 14 or over and which will oblige the Court, rather, to consider any wishes which are expressed by a child of any age. Even with this proposed amendment I am still personally concerned about the possibility of pressure being brought to bear on a child by one or other parent in a custody proceeding in order to extract from the child a favourable expression of wishes. I think that this possibility, which I suspect is a very real one, not only underlies the importance of separate representation for the child but also calls for some kind of guarantee that evidence as to a child's wishes, if that is to be led in a Family Court proceeding, should be attested to by a person truly independent of the child's parents. At the appropriate time I propose to move an amendment to that effect.

So far as counselling is concerned, I start, as I suspect many honourable senators do, from the premise that contested family law cases, particularly over custody matters which are the most gruelling of them all, must be avoided at all costs. The complexity of the problems involved, the intensity of the feeling of the parties and the virtual impossibility of achieving a result which will be suitable and acceptable to all parties without any demur make adversary proceedings and the judicial arbitration of that contest singularly inappropriate to the resolution of this class of family law problem. Those involved with the court do a very conscientious job in this respect but if we can possibly avoid the matter coming to arbitation in that way, that is a wholly salutary objective to be pursuing.

I welcome very much the trend towards the early intervention in disputed family law cases, by counselling services to analyse the problems and to explore possible solutions in an atmosphere of negotiation rather than confrontation. Pre-court counselling, as it is described, has a success rate of 80 per cent to 90 per cent; that is, the parties settle their disputes and reach agreement over custody and access in that proportion of cases. I think it is so obvious as to not need further repetition that the earlier the intervention the better in this respect. If that is to occur, if there is to be earlier intervention, if there is to be more systematic intervention in this helping, negotiating counselling way, there is an obvious need for more counsellors to do that pre-court work. On current figures, if such counsellors were made available, this would undoubtedly further reduce the number of contested matters and would reduce delays that are presently operating within the counselling services.

The other pre-court intervention that is particularly crucial-I am not talking about the custody area this time but rather about contested property matters or financial matters-is the intervention which is made by deputy registrars. To the extent that they participate in the pre-trial resolution of contested property matters, they have been achieving a settlement rate of about 70 per cent. Once again, I believe that all the evidence suggests that were more resources to be made available in this respect an even higher proportion of settled as distinct from contested, matters could, in fact, be achieved. This, indeed, was recommended quite explicitly by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act both in respect of financial intervention and custody counselling. It is obvious , I suggest to the chamber, that mediation and counselling, both within the court system and, of course, supplemented by such services outside it, is an infinitely better route to the successful resolution of the whole series of complex situations that arise in respect of divorce proceedings than costly and drawn out legal battles.

The remaining specific matter that I mention as crying out for attention within the system as it operates at the moment concerns the enforcement of orders of the Family Court. This is undoubtedly one of the biggest areas of complaint that I see in practice; that is, non-compliance with court orders, notably those relating to access and maintenance. We are talking about continuing or recurrent obligations which may be met by the recipient of the order for a significant period but then allowed to lapse or in other cases are never complied with at all. At one level, there will never be an ultimate solution to this problem of enforcement, no one can compel compliance if the party bound to comply is absolutely intransigent. The final sanction has to be punishment simply for contempt of court either by fine or imprisonment, but that still does not ensure money in the hands of the party to whom that money is supposed to be going. The deterrent quality of such punishment is important. I certainly support its retention as a last resort, but it will not solve the hard cases which number perhaps one in 20 on the figures that have been suggested to me. In any case, both financial and custodial penalties can place even further burdens on innocent parties, particularly the children.

Short of those really hard cases, there are some things which I believe can be done. I will mention a couple of them. One is to clarify the role of State police so that they are required and know that they are required to give assistance in enforcing Family Court orders. At present the reality of the matter is that State police refuse to assist except in the execution of a Family Court warrant when they are expressly requested by the Federal Police to do so. I believe it is unfair that people who have court orders should be prevented by these time honoured demarcation questions and by the absence of a significant Federal Police presence in many areas of Australia from enforcing their rights. The parliamentary Committee recommended that section 112 of the Act be utilised for the purpose of making the necessary arrangements with State police to formalise their role in the enforcement of custody and access. According to the Attorney-General's initial statement, this was to be dealt with in the Bill, but it certainly does not appear to have been. I would have thought it was clearly an Executive matter rather than a legislative one under section 112. I would welcome some explanation from the Attorney-General in that respect if he is mindful to offer it in his reply to the second reading debate.

The other solution which ought to be seriously considered is the creation of some special maintenance enforcement agency and appropriate procedures to go with it. That was another recommendation of the parliamentary Committee; that is , the creation of a national agency to administer the collection and enforcement of maintenance. Recommendation 31 of that Committee's report set out a list of 12 steps, all of which I believe should be taken seriously, to improve procedures for the enforcement of maintenance. Those recommendations have, however, with just one exception, not been taken up, although we are told that some of them are still under consideration. All I would say at this stage is that a maintenance order which is unenforceable is obviously worse than having no order at all. It is essential that this whole matter be given far more urgent attention than it seems to be receiving from the Attorney-General. So much for some of the specific matters which were given rise to by the terms of this Bill.

Finally, I want to say something about the role of the legal system in the administration of family law. This seems to be me to of quite fairly fundamental importance. For large numbers of Australians, family law is the most important part of the legal system with which they ever have contact in their entire lives . Yet family law remains the cinderella of legal practice. I should say right at the outset that I personally have very considerable admiration for the hardy band of family law practitioners who are, by and large, dedicated, patient and understanding. In my present position as a member of parliament-I know this goes for many honourable senators and members-I and my staff see a very large number of constituents on family law matters. I know just how difficult these cases are to solve. They do not admit of easy legal solutions because the legal rights and duties laid down by the Act are really only the beginning of the answer. We are dealing, in addition, with very srong emotions, with people's personal lives and , most importantly, with broad discretions which the Family Court is called upon to exercise and which are simply not susceptible to objective legal analysis after the event in the way that is perhaps more common in other jurisdictions.

It is perhaps the very difficulty of the jurisdiction, the lack of legal certaintly, and the demand it places upon qualities of patience and compassion which results, perhaps perversely, in family law practice being disparaged by the vast majority of legal practitioners. That is probably, however, being rather over-charitable. To my knowledge, family law practice is widely perceived as being lowly in status, tainted by legal aid funding and is ultimately unremunerative, at least by comparison with the golden eggs laid by the untiring commercial law goose. It is not entirely unremunerative, of course. Under regulation 183 I notice that the basic return for the undefended divorce under the scale rate is something like $275 where children are involved and $210 where they are not. Some people have been unkind enough to suggest that this is money for jam. Nevertheless, generally speaking, family law is unremunerative and in the hard cases there is certainly no question of the harrowing strain this places on legal practitioners being compensated for in any of the ways that are normally thought usual in this profession.

These attitudes-they are attitudes about the practice of family law which I deplore-go much of the way, I think, to explaining the decision of most large solicitors' firms and many quite able barristers to refuse family law work entirely, or at least, to treat it as suitable for the female articled clerk and no one else. The end result tends to be that family law becomes the poor relation. Most of those who count themselves among the leading lawyers in the land would not be seen dead within the portals of the Family Court. I think that is a lamentable situation, a perversion of priorities. Family law, dealing as it does with the most initimate affairs of real people, is just too important to too many people to be relegated to the bottom of the legal pecking order. On this occasion I invite the legal community, the legal profession, to take a long , hard look at itself in that respect.

Another aspect of the legal profession is the role of family law judges. All the qualities demanded of family law practitioners are demanded a dozen times over of family court judges. They are called on to display superhuman skills; to be psychologist, social worker, counsellor and arbitrator all rolled into one- combining the wisdom of Solomon with the patience of Job. It is perhaps not surprising, given those demands, that not all of them in practice measure up to that standard. But theirs is an unenviable task. The death recently of one Family Court judge in tragic circumstances is a shocking reminder of the passion which their decisions do in fact generate among those whom they affect and the risks they run in exercising a role in this jurisdiction. I repeat the call I made previously, during a debate last year on the Judges Pensions Amendment Bill , that the salaries of family law court judges need to be upgraded to ensure a remuneration in keeping with the very heavy responsibility they bear and to ensure that persons of the highest calibre can be attracted.

It is evident that the job of improving the Family Law Act and the whole family law system to make it more workable and more equitable is by no means going to be completed by the passage of this amendment Bill, even in its original form and without the emasculation I know that has been contemplated by a number of honourable senators and members-including Senator Martyr, who is to follow me in this debate. The passage of this Bill, particularly if it is further amended in some of the ways I have recommended tonight, will certainly go a long way in making the system work a lot better than it does at the moment.

Family law is a real challenge for any legal system-for the legislators who are out to make the law and for the lawyers who have to apply it and to administer it. I do not underestimate the task of getting that system right. But I believe great strides have been made both in the passage of the original Act and now in the presentation of this amending Bill. The task of maintaining a degree of momentum in the development of the law and the amendment of the law so it can match changing social realities is difficult and sensitive. However, it is a task that must continue. It will continue only if all honourable senators and members in debating this Bill adopt-as I hope most of us will, but I fear some of us may not-a constructive and forward-looking approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Prior to the Family Law Act most people stayed married more or less satisfactorily. In fact, there were 250,357 divorces and 311,080 children were involved with divorce. If honourable senators have already forgotten I will remind them that staying together for the sake of the children was a form of voluntary and often heroic self-sacrifice and self-denial to help the children. Today this sounds strangely antiquated in an era when everyone does his own thing regardless of whose interests are hurt. Unfortunately, this has become the tragic basic philosophy of what passes for law in the Family Law Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The so-called progressives-always a very powerful influence with their allies the media-to get their form of divorce legislation, offered a most attractive bait. They said: 'You will be able to do as you like in marriage and not have to face the full responsibility of your conduct; being divorced as a guilty party'. A group of professionals with legal training and an apparent vested interest in easy divorce lobbied parliamentarians prior to 1975, day and night. I have heard them disrespectfully referred to as 'a gang of touts and urgers' but they are not my words; I quote somebody else. Some of these people have since benefited substantially in the law from their dedication. Some of them are judges and advocates in this most lucrative jurisdiction.

Mr Justice Murphy and his force of libertarians, undoubtedly supported by Senator Evans then outside the Parliament, and so-called progressives from both sides of this Parliament-who in my opinion did not know the difference between liberty and licence and who still do not and who again in my opinion did not much care-erred solidly on the side of licence and were finally supported by only a narrow majority in this Parliament. But that was enough and their writ runs today in the tragedy of the Family Law Act. In 1979, after only four years of this infamous Act, it was necessary because of public outcry to have a joint parliamentary select committee of both Houses of Parliament, which sat for a whole year, inquiring into the operation of the Act. This monumental effort with its mountain of evidence produced a majority report and several minority reports . Not for one moment do I question the genuineness of those who agreed to the majority report; I question only their judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were by yourself; you were Robinson Crusoe.

—They had a damn sight less bias than Senator Evans did. The majority report decided to by-pass the ample evidence of the deep discontent caused by the working of the Act. This, I suppose, was almost inevitable. Obviously, the professionals convinced the Committee that Parliament cannot reform society through the law and that the law should therefore reflect only what they think are current mores. How easy it is to wipe off the cries of anguish of the outraged innocents punished harshly by the operation of the Act by saying that it is never possible to satisfy an unsuccessful litigant.

SPEECH.PARA: We were told in our inquiry by the professionals that no one is innocent. I must say that this is a refreshing change when the same people say in an argumentative contest of a theological kind that there is no such thing as original sin and therefore everyone is innocent. If anybody wants a clear and demonstrable argument about how the law does influence behaviour and attitudes there are many such demonstrations. There is the classic example of seatbelt laws where law certainly has influenced behaviour. There is another instance that some honourable senators may not like to hear but it is intensely relevant. Since the breaking down of the laws by judicial interpretations-it should be noted they were brought about by pleas about the hard cases that make bad laws-the numbers have risen to staggering heights. Here the change in the interpretation and application of the law changed something that was regarded as a disgusting crime just a few years ago into something socially acceptable and therefore right and proper behaviour widely practised, even encouraged.

I return to the majority report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. Those who are responsible for the Family Law Act forgot one very important thing and I think Senator Evans has forgotten it too. If one repeals a rule one must beware of the evil which the rule was intended to combat. Thus the Joint Select Committee's fundamental mistake was that it ignored the destruction of innocence and denial of justice perpetrated by the Family Law Act. Yet those were the very things which precipitated calls for the Joint Select Committee to investigate the operation of the Act. In spite of my emotions I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my findings after the inquiry of the Joint Select Committee into the Family Law Act which sum up far better than what I have said so far what I think about it.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Summary of Findings
1. The Family Law Act is a divorce Act only, and has contributed substantially to the breakdown of marriage and family as a permanent commitment.

2. The Family Law Act purports to uphold marriage, but in effect makes marriage an unforceable contract, with 12 months' separation as the only ground for legal 'no fault' unilateral breaking of the contract.
3. The Family Law Act has no priority for annulment applications.
4. The Family Law Act has abolished innocence and therefore its judgments cannot be based on complete justice.

5. The Family Law Act, in abolishing innocence, has caused confusion by allowing sociology, through court counsellors, into what are and should always be essentially matters of law. Sociology is inherently inexact; the law tries to be exact about innocence and guilt-thus the confusion.
6. The Family Law Act allows divorcees to start a new domestic life before ALL matters are settled. This causes more confusion and difficulty, particularly for children.

7. The Family Law Act allows trial and judgment in secret. The law must always be open to the public and its proceedings and findings open for publication, with proper protection for the under age only.

8. The Family Law Act, paricularly through ''no fault'' divorce, has separated Family Law from the mainstream of Australian jurisprudence. There is also a special condition in the Family Law Act for appointment as a Judge of the Family Court, and there are different premises, procedures, rules and customs, which are unnecessary and undesirable.

9. The Family Law Act is enormously expensive to the taxpayer. It has created a heavy structure of judges and extra bureaucracy, with more to come with the Institute of Family Studies. Only rarely has cost of proceedings been excessive. Excessive fee appeals before Registrars, if successful, do not have costs of appeal awarded as in other courts.
10. The Family Law Council is performing work which should be the sole province of the Parliament.
11. The Institute of Family Studies will add nothing to marriage stability and permanence.
12. The Family Court has no machinery for reconciliation counselling. Its '' court counsellors'' are essentially expediters of court procedures.
13. The Family Law Act's ''no fault'' divorce has confused marriage counselling organisations to the point where they are vague about their purpose. They feel no real support from the Family Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. We now have the long-awaited response from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to the Joint Select Committee's report. —Ha, ha!

—Senator Evans may laugh but they represent people. The document read as follows-
(d) Procedure followed by the Committee in regard to taking testimony from, and being involved on the Committee with, the judiciary of the Family Court and the Family Law Council.

In regard to point (d) above, I objected to taking testimony from, and being involved on the Joint Select Committee with, the Judiciary of Family Court and the Family Law Council. My objections were raised at, and rejected by, a deliberative meeting of the Joint Select Committee. However, I hold those objections still, and note that the Committee finally apparently agreed in part: on 7th November, the Chairman rejected an offer from the Family Law Council to again meet with us and his rejection was supported by a deliberative meeting of the Committee.

My basic objections are, I believe, well founded in the concept of liberty well expressed by Montesquieu. He says, ''In every government there are three sorts of power: the legislative; the executive in respect of things dependent on the law of nations; and the executive in regard to matters that depend on the civil law (the latter we shall call the judiciary power) . . . There is no liberty if the judiciary power be not separated from the legislative and executive. Were it joined with the legislative, the life and liberty of the subject would be exposed to arbitrary control, for the judge would then be the legislator.

The Joint Select Committee Chairman himself had much the same thing to say in a speech reported in House of Representatives Hansard p. 2917, 13th November, 1979 , in the debate on the High Court of Australia Bill. He said, ''Liberty has long been dependent on the independence of the functions that each of the areas of government have in our system and their effective separation.''

Also on Thursday 10th April 1980, at a deliberative meeting of the Joint Select Committee, Mr Holding M.P. and Senator Missen and others upheld this principle when they disagreed with the suggestion that the Joint Select Committee should recommend a pool of judges from which appelate judges can be drawn to constitute Full Benches, on the ground that this prerogative must remain with the Chief Judge as head of the Family Law judiciary, and the Parliament must not interfere .

I believe in the validity of this principle of separation, and regretfully express the view that this Joint Committee should not have heard the Family Law Council and the Family Law Court judges (I exclude from this Judge Nygh, appointed to the Bench after his submission to our inquiry and who appeared as an individual.) Division of the Family Court, at one hearing in Perth at which I was present actually directed a member of his staff giving evidence NOT TO ANSWER a question I asked, and the question was not answered.

In my view the appearances of the judges constituted a breakdown of the proper traditional separation of judiciary and Parliament, and may have damaged the over-riding integrity of the Parliamentary role, which must never be seen even remotely as being pressured by the judiciary.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'that', insert-

'The Bill be withdrawn to enable a new Bill to be redrafted which consolidates the provision of the Family Law Act 1975 and the Marriage Act 1961 to govern the making, subsistance and, if necessary, dissolution of marriage, and which provides for:
(a) the establishment within the institution of marriage of the principle of preparation for, permanence of, and commitment to, marriage, including marriage contracts;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be as fast in speaking to the Bills as Senator Walsh. I have a far deeper interest in the poultry industry than Senator Walsh, having been a poultry farmer and an egg producer before I became a senator. I have a lot of sympathy for the egg producers in Australia and the problems that they have faced over many years. I commence my remarks by saying that the egg industry is very proud of the way it has never called upon the Government for subsidies to finance the industry when things have been going badly. They have always been prepared to get themselves out of their own problems-unlike many primary producers who, when things go bad, call upon the Government to get financial support to get them out of the problems. There is a well known saying that the policy of the National Country Party has always been to socialise losses and capitalise profits. That could never be said truthfully about egg producers in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a little astounded when I look at the time that it took to introduce the two second reading speeches to these Bills which we are debating cognately. When the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) introduced them in the House of Representatives on 18 February he introduced the first Bill at 2.39 p.m. and the second one at 2.40 p.m.-it took a minute to read the first second reading speech and it took a minute to read the second one because the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill came on at 2.41 p.m. So, those two major Bills took two minutes to introduce by way of second reading speeches.

I will confine my remarks to the Egg (Export Inspection Charge) Bill. The Government expects to raise $145,000 in a full year from the egg export inspection charges. Of course, if some State Ministers have their way this amount will be quite a bit in excess of $145,000, particularly if there is no change of government in Victoria in a fortnight's time. If Mr Austin, the present Minister of Agriculture, is returned to office and carries out the promises of his predecessor, Mr Smith, a Victorian Liberal government will phase out the hen quota system. Then, of course, we will go back to the Rafferty's rules situation which we were in in the early 1960s in the egg industry. It will be a dog eat dog situation. Under the protection of section 92 of the Constitution eggs will be moving to and fro across the border and no one will be able to ascertain whether, in fact, the eggs were transported across the border or whether they were produced in the State where they are retailed, as happened when there was a type of civil war in the egg industry when I was a poultry farmer in the early 1960s until 1970 when I came into this place.

I was very grateful that when I left the egg industry and became a senator it appeared that we were getting some stability in the egg industry. It now appears that some of the monopolies are trying to get control of the industry. If governments are not very careful we will see ourselves engaged in another egg war. Of course, the conclusion of that war will mean that consumers will not get cheaper eggs; they will get dearer eggs and eggs of poorer quality. In the 1960s and early 1970s the so-called free enterprise people would pick up eggs from a haystack or from under a boxthorn bush and sell them to the consumer. The interested consumer wants farm fresh eggs; there is no such thing because there is no guarantee that, in fact, the eggs are fresh. The only guarantee that we have today that an egg is fresh is an Egg Board brand on it. If a person finds an egg that is not of good quality he than has the opportunity to return it to the retailer to have it replaced. But no such thing can happen when a consumer buys an unbranded egg.

My colleague in the other place, the Labor spokesman on Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, in speaking on this legislation pointed out that Mr Smith, the previous Minister of Agriculture in Victoria, had made some suggestions about phasing out the quota system. As I have said, Mr Austin, his successor, is very non- committal now because an election is in the offing in Victoria. When he was asked what he was going to do about continuing with Mr Smith's promise to phase out the industry he was very non-committal. He said: 'Oh, we will wait until after the Victorian election'. I can tell any egg producer who is listening tonight that if by some quirk of fate the Liberals are re-elected-I do not think they will be-

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially after tonight.

—Especially after what has happened tonight. Those who saw the Australian Broadcasting Commission news at 9.50 p.m. were acquainted with the fact that the senior Ministers of this Government have been meeting in great trauma all day to discuss the possible challenge to the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by Mr Peacock. Anything could happen. At this time I am concerned in the main about egg producers and egg consumers. I return to what I was saying-that Mr Austin is non-committal as to what he may do, if he is returned to office at the end of next week, about continuing with Mr Smith's promise to phase out the quota system, which would be disastrous for the family egg producer in Australia and also disastrous for the egg consumer. Let us hope that Mr Austin is not returned and that there is a Labor Minister of Agriculture in Victoria who has some concern for the egg producers and the consumers, as had Mr Bywaters who became Minister for Agriculture in South Australia in 1965. He agreed with Mr Adermann's legislation, that we ought to implement the plan of the Council of Egg Marketing Authorities of Australia. That helped to bring about some stability in the egg industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party, when in government, has always been concerned about the welfare not only of primary producers but also of consumers. It has been concerned to see that both sides get a fair go-that is, that the producer receives a fair price for his commodity and that the consumer does not pay an exorbitant price. Mr Kerin went on to point out in the other place that last year Australia exported 1.6 million dozen eggs and 8.9 kilotonnes of egg pulp. As I pointed out, if people such as Mr Austin carry out the threats of Mr Smith we could see within the next 12 months a much larger exportable surplus. Instead of egg producers paying $145,000 by way of export charge levy they could well be paying double that amount. Unfortunately, a lot of them will go out of business.

Mr Kerin also pointed out that following the increase in the number of eggs produced the percentage of the commercial production being sold on the export market rose from 8.7 per cent to 13.1 per cent last year. What we are saying is that Australia is selling on the export market at virtually a loss. Of course, when we have a surplus of egg production in this country we have to sell it overseas at a loss. Some people wonder why it is sold at a loss. They cannot understand the fact that a lot of the eggs which are sold overseas, particularly the pasteurised pulp, has to be kept in cold storage at an enormous cost. This has to be borne by the local producer. It is unfortunate that that happens. I give great credit to the egg industry and the Australian Egg Board, under the chairmanship of Mr Ray Fuge, who is well known to me. It has endeavoured strongly to bring about some stability in the egg industry, to bring about an equitable amount of production so that we are not faced with a surplus. It also has attempted to ensure that no monopoly takes place in the industry.

It is unfortunate that under a Liberal Government in New South Wales some years ago, when the CEMA plan came into operation, and in particular the quota system, the sky was the limit in that State. In my own State there is a maximum limit and no one producer could have more than 50,000 birds. That, I think, is more than enough for any one producer to make a very good living out of eggs. In New South Wales the Liberal Government allowed the sky to be the limit. I am very pleased to know that the New South Wales Wran Labor Government is looking at placing a maximum limit on the number of birds that any one producer can have in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Hallam is a very capable Minister.

—I agree entirely with the honourable senator. At present he is having an inquiry into the egg industry in order to see that some stability can be brought about, not only for New South Wales but also for every State in Australia. I have spoken about eggs very often in this Parliament. When I looked back at the Hansard record I saw that I made my maiden speech in this place nearly 11 years ago. As a matter of fact I made it on 15 September 1971 and I spoke about eggs. At that time I warned the Senate of the problems the egg industry was facing because of overproduction. We have had that problem ever since. I must point out that I am not now engaged in the egg industry but I take a great interest in it. Egg producers and their organisation have made a determined effort to bring about some stability in the industry so that we do not have a large surplus of eggs. A large surplus does not do anybody any good. It does not bring cheaper eggs to the consumer and it does not bring a decent living to the producer. I will quote only a few of the words from my maiden speech in 1971:

SPEECH.PARA: For years past poultry farmers through their organisations have acquainted all State Ministers of Agriculture with this problem-
I was talking about a surplus of eggs-

and have pleaded with them to come to agreement at Australian Agricultural Council meetings, which are under the chairmanship of the Federal Minister for Primary Industry, on a plan for controlled production of eggs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What year was that?
—That was in 1971, and I was sitting where Senator Mulvihill is sitting now when I made my maiden speech. I expressed my concern then about the egg industry.
—It went unheeded.

—No, it did not go unheeded, because we got some stability. Unfortunately, however, the powers that be, the great monopolies, are now beginning to get another grip on the industry, endeavouring to force out the family farmer. Many senators who sit opposite say that members of the Australian Labor Party have no concern with the primary producers, particularly family farmers. If they were prepared to read Hansard, they would see that that is not true. Because of our policies we continually support them, and not only in this Parliament. We fully support the family farmer and the small producer, as against the monopoly farmer, and the Rundle Street farmer, the Pitt Street farmer and the Collins Street farmer. We have no sympathy for them and we have expressed that view many times in this Parliament, but we are misrepresented by the National Country Party and the Liberal Party on every occasion when it comes to election time.
—Where do you stand with the Murray Bridge farmers?

—The Murray Bridge farmers are just the same, probably, as the farmers in your area or any other area. They are all together. We have concern for all of them. We do not select them out on a parochial basis, and we do not pork barrel them either.

SPEECH.PARA: Even 11 years ago, I had incorporated in Hansard an answer that I received to a question of mine from Senator Drake-Brockman when he was a member of this Parliament. Referring to his answer, I said:
It can be clearly seen that it is the Victorian Minister of Agriculture alone who is preventing this plan of controlled production being put to the poultry farmers by way of a referendum.
I said:
What sort of society are we living in when the pigheadedness of one man can put a nationwide industry in jeopardy?

That is the problem with which we are faced in the egg industry, and that is the problem that Mr Adermann was faced with as Minister for Primary Industry in a Menzies Government. He could not get the consensus of all the State agricultural Ministers in Australia. It is sad to say that at that time with the CEMA plan the person who was at odds with Mr Adermann was Mr David Brookman, who was the Minister of Agriculture in South Australia. He would not agree with Mr Adermann because Mr Adermann had suggested that he would not implement the legislation passed by both Houses of this Parliament until all State agriculture Ministers agreed. David Brookman would not agree. But when we got a change of government in 1965, Mr Bywaters, who lived in the same town as I did and was well conversant with problems of the poultry industry, readily agreed. So the legislation was implemented, and we have gone on from there. But unfortunately, what happened? Gabe Bywaters got the blame for the introduction of the legislation. It was thought that it was Labor legislation, not Liberal legislation. He lost his seat in 1968, and we lost a Labor government in South Australia because we were trying to protect poultry producers. They have regretted it ever since. It is often said that Gabe Bywaters was the best Minister of Agriculture that South Australia ever had. Many of the people who voted him out of office because he did away with their free trade over the border have regretted it ever since.

I think that I have put my case. I have expressed my concern and that of the many people in the poultry industry who have contacted me, that, if governments do not take some consideration and cognisance of what we are saying we shall fall back into the problems that we experienced in the early 1960s-chaos in the egg marketing industry. I sound this warning tonight to all governments, not only this Government but the State governments, particularly the Victorian Government, which I hope will not be re-elected: Do not do anything drastic that will take away the livelihood of the family egg producer and, in particular, take away the good quality egg which the consumer is now receiving. As Senator Walsh, who led for the Opposition on these Bills, said, we support the legislation with the warning that, if due consideration is not given to overproduction and if production gets out of hand, there is a possibility that the egg producers, instead of having to find $145,000 in the next 12 months as an egg export levy as envisaged in this legislation, will have to find double or treble that amount.

I am told that as he left the chamber Mrs McLaren said to him: 'Geoff, they will be quoting that speech in years to come'. I am delighted that she has been proven so right 11 years later. TALK.START.PARA: —The Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982 and the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1982 are identical in purpose to the three groups of Bills which have just been passed. Their purpose is to impose and collect an inspection levy or fee for inspecting exports which fee is designed to cover half the actual costs of providing the export inspection service. I understand that Senator Peter Rae or someone from the Government side will be moving at the conclusion of the second reading debate that these two Bills be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for investigation and report by the middle of the year or thereabouts. This investigation is regarded as something of a test case for the inspection services, in this area to see whether the Senate Committee can detect areas in which improvements in efficiency and reductions in cost are attainable. If the Committee should be so persuaded in respect of honey inspection services I would expect a more wide ranging investigation by the Finance and Government Operations Committee of other inspection services.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been claimed to me, and I think to other members of parliament, that the proposed charge which is in excess of $6 a tonne for honey is excessive when viewed against charges for other perishable commodities such as dairy products, which I think will have a levy of about $2.50 a tonne. I do not accept that it necessarily follows that a charge is excessive because it is 2 1/2 times the charge imposed on some other product. The basis of levying these charges is not the perishability of the product or the value of the product; the basis on which the charges are levied is one of cost. One may or may not disagree with that being an appropriate basis for determining the charges but the cost of providing a service does not necessarily bear any relation to the value of the product or to the quantity of the product being inspected. That is one of the matters which I would expect the Committee ultimately will take into consideration.

It has also been alleged that in some specific instances, which I will not go into now, there are identifiable instances of inefficiency on the part of the Department of Primary Industry inspection services with respect to honey inspection. I do not propose to detail those allegations now, much less pass judgment on their validity or otherwise. That is a matter for the Committee to investigate at the appropriate time. The Opposition will not be opposing the second readings of the Bills and will support the motion to refer them to the Finance and Government Operations Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a relatively small group of primary producers, the honey producers and beekeepers certainly have done their homework as far as the honey inspection charge legislation is concerned. I have had a considerable number of calls and messages not only from Tasmania but also from a variety of places around Australia. The industry is facing a fairly difficult period. Apparently this is mainly as a result of very heavy sales of honey from China, which has brought down the price by probably $200 a tonne on an Australian average. The situation in relation to international markets is quite difficult as supply is high. The industry has had a lot of difficulty trying to cope with varying Australian exchange rates. It has suffered enormous problems with shipping and the markets have varied considerably from place to place. The honey producers make up a relatively small group and as far as shipping is concerned unfortunately they get treated that way, particularly in comparison with the producers of larger items of primary produce such as wool and meat or of minerals and things of that nature.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian honey is of a very high quality and the inspection service has been able to maintain that. But the markets that the honey producers have been shipping to have been very difficult because of the unreliability of being able to get their product into the right place at the right time. In many cases the markets have been lost because of the unreliability of shipping. Beekeeping is carried on right throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But nowhere produces honey as good as the leatherwood in Tasmania, does it.

—No. Beekeeping has been a great hobby for a lot of people and is a very important business as well. In any of the cropping areas beekeeping is a most important subsidiary industry. The general fertilisation that ensures the productivity of crops is influenced enormously by the adequacy of the bee populations in those areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will hold up the Parliament for only 3 1/2 minutes. I refer to Administrative Bulletin 82/10 issued on Paddy's Day, 17 March 1982. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: STAFF ACCESS TO NON-MEMBERS' BAR.
I think my remarks are more properly directed to you, Mr President, than to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Peter Baume). The Bulletin continues:

All staff are reminded that access to the non-Members' bar is prohibited during working hours. This means that the non-Members' bar is not to be frequented by a House of Representatives staff member--

from the time of commencing duty to the time of ceasing duty, excluding the staff member's recognised lunch and dinner periods.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean senators and members?

—Yes, senators and members, including the President. It will mean that other people working in this place will not be allowed to have access to the non-members' bar. This matter was raised with me, incidentally, by an absolute teetotaller. He does have an addiction to Coca Cola and likes to go and get a can of Coke during his morning tea breaks. I recall something of this kind happening years ago when I worked in a trade. My then 4* year old daughter had been admitted to hospital with an acute appendix problem and was operated on. I remember going to my then boss and saying: 'Can I ring the hospital to see how my little daughter is during morning tea?' He said: 'No way. You cannot use an office phone'. I said: 'I am prepared to pay for the use of the office phone', which in those days cost four or five pence. He said: 'No way'. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to two decisions which have been made in recent times by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority which have had an impact on the community. The first was a decision last year to increase the price of letting school halls and facilities to community groups. It has been the practice in this community for some 20 years or more to encourage groups to use the school halls and not to seek to have other community facilities built. This has worked very well until just recently. The decision to increase the hire of school halls is a decision which was probably made quite reasonably within the context of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. The Authority's primary function, of course, is to run the school system and to see that its funds are devoted towards that end. But the increased cost of using school halls for community purposes has had a quite serious impact on a number of groups. I mention just one. The Canberra marching girls used to meet at Lyneham primary school twice a week, on each occasion for three hours. That group paid $7 a session-$14 a week. The new price is $5 per hour which means that the group has to pay $15 per session or $30 per week. As I say, from the Schools Authority point of view that is perhaps a defensible decision, but given that we do not have the same number of old institutes, old church halls and buildings of that nature in this city people have become used to using school halls and this change has imposed a hardship.

SPEECH.PARA: The other decision was to rationalise the use of school buildings to try to get more groups to use one school and then not use another. This decision also has upset a number of groups. It is not really desirable to have, for example, young boy scouts travelling on their bikes from one suburb to another in a way that some are now being asked to do. Certainly the Schools Authority is working on refinements of this arrangement but there really has been a serious change in direction in the way the community has been asked to use schools in the past. The same situation does not exist in any State. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a document which I have had prepared.
