TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 February 1982 (Hansard, page 14), Senator Peter Rae asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: What research work has been undertaken to assess which industries and which areas in Australia will be most adversely affected if the closer economic relations with New Zealand proposals go ahead? If such work has been undertaken , what are the results and will they be made available? If the work has not been undertaken, will the Minister put to his colleague a suggestion that the work should be undertaken before any further discussions take place with New Zealand?
The Minister for Trade and Resurces has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In accordance with guidelines contained in the Joint Communique issued by the Australian and New Zealand Prime Ministers in Wellington in March 1980, officials on both sides have undertaken a series of studies on methods and detailed arrangements by which the two governments might proceed to implement progressive moves towards a closer trans-Tasman economic relationship (CER).

A report by officials was presented to the two governments early in 1981. The report contained the basis of possible new trading arrangements, including those for the gradual and progressive elimination of tariffs and quantitative restrictions and measures to ensure fair competition in trans-Tasman trade. The report indicated that officials had established a broad area of common ground. However, as confirmed by the Minister for Trade and Resources in discussions with Prime Minister Muldoon and other New Zealand Ministers in May 1981, differences of view remained in respect of a number of issues which are seen as fundamental to any new agreement. These include the setting of a firm date for the ultimate elimination of quantitative restrictions between the two countries , the future of performance-based export incentives in trans-Tasman trade, the position of dairy products under a CER, and sensitive horticulture issues.

Officials have continued to study these and other outstanding questions, and as appropriate, consultations have taken place between Australian and New Zealand industry groups including the two dairy industries. Senior officials meetings are to be held in April, as preparation for early Ministerial level negotiations aimed at reaching agreement on a CER package which could then be submitted to the two governments for final decision.

Several of the issues identified for study by the Prime Ministers reflected recognition of the fact that further liberalisation of trans-Tasman trade could have an unfair adverse impact on certain industries in each country given differences in the nature and extent of agricultural support/stabilisation arrangements, export incentive schemes and tariffs applied against third countries. It was also necessary to take account of such factors in devising possible new trading arrangements.

Any assessment of the potential impact of a CER on Australian industries needs to have regard to features of the trading framework that has evolved under NAFTA. Under existing arrangements, imports from New Zealand enter Australia either free or at very low rates of duty. New Zealand exporters also have the benefit of generous performance-based export incentive arrangements. On the other hand, many Australian exports to New Zealand face duties which are generally higher and are further restricted by import licensing. Under an appropriately structured CER, these and other factors contributing to inequality of trading opportunity and unfair competition would be gradually removed. The proposed new arrangements would have, as their primary purpose, the elimination of imbalances in opportunity confronting Australian producers in trans-Tasman trade.

It is not expected that any Australian industries would be adversely affected at the outset of a CER. However, over time it could be expected that some rationalisation and restructuring of industry would occur with the removal of trade barriers leading to increased trade and competition between the two countries. However the gradualism inherent in CER mechanisms should ensure that any adjustment pressures in either country can be accommodated. Overall, such pressures are unlikely to be of major significance when compared with those occurring within the domestic economy and as a result of Australia's trade with the rest of the world.

It should be noted that consultations with State governments and interested industry oranisations have been held at key stages in the CER exercise. The Government is committed to making public the proposed new arrangements and consulting fully with interested parties before final decisions are taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 March 1982 (Hansard, page 576) Senator Ryan asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the 12-point program for the advancement of women announced yesterday by the Government of France to mark International Women's Day? Will the Government undertake to examine the French initiatives, which are reported to include increased family allowances and pensions for women, laws to promote equality and to prohibit sex discrimination, reform of the laws on alimony and common property and reform of discriminatory tax laws? Is the Government prepared to make a commitment to Australian women similar to the commitment made to French women by the Government of France?
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of press reports of an announcement made by the Government of France to mark International Women's Day. The Australian Government is committed to freedom from discrimination, equality of opportunity and equal status for women, and I applaud any movement in this direction nationally or internationally.
I am not able to comment further on the French initiatives until I am able to study them in detail. I will undertake to examine these initiatives and report further to the honourable senator.
